title: I devoutly believe it is the writer who has matured the film medium more than anyone else in Hollywood. Even when he knew nothing about his work, he brought at least knowledge of life and a more grown-up mind, a maturer feeling about the human being.

author: Albert Einstein
title: I do not believe in immortality of the individual, and I consider ethics to be an exclusively human concern with no superhuman authority behind it.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: I do not hesitate to read all good books in translations. What is really best in any book is translatable - any real insight or broad human sentiment.

author: Honoré de Balzac
title: I do not regard a broker as a member of the human race.

author: Antonio Tabucchi
title: I don't have any doubts either about the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Perhaps some more should be added to the list, but I don't have the slightest doubt about human rights.

author: Bob Dylan
title: I don't think the human mind can comprehend the past and the future. They are both just illusions that can manipulate you into thinking there's some kind of change.

author: Stephen Hawking
title: I don't think the human race will survive the next thousand years, unless we spread into space. ,

author: Pearl S. Buck
title: I feel no need for any other faith than my faith in the kindness of human beings. I am so absorbed in the wonder of earth and the life upon it that I cannot think of heaven and angels.

author: Marianne Williamson
title: I fell in love with the thought that a human life could be a priestly conduit, a connecting link between earth and sky. As I grew and stumbled and, most important, as I began to love and be loved, I realized that the ultimate priest is the lover inside us

author: P. D. James
title: I find it extraordinary that a straightforward if inelegant device for ensuring the survival of the species should involve human beings in such emotional turmoil. Does sex have to be taken so seriously?

author: William Hazlitt
title: I hate to be near the sea, and to hear it roaring and raging like a wild beast in its den. It puts me in mind of the everlasting efforts of the human mind, struggling to be free, and ending just where it began.

author: Benjamin Tucker
title: I have also seen it stated that Capital punishment is murder in its worst form. I should like to know upon what principle of human society these assertions are based and justified.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: I have always considered it as treason against the great republic of human nature, to make any man's virtues the means of deceiving him.

author: Benjamin Disraeli
title: I have brought myself, by long meditation, to the conviction that a human being with a settled purpose must accomplish it, and that nothing can resist a will which will stake even existence upon its fulfillment.

author: Blaise Pascal
title: I have discovered that all human evil comes from this, man's being unable to sit still and quiet in a room alone.

author: Sigmund Freud
title: I have found little that is ''good'' about human beings on the whole. In my experience most of them are trash, no matter whether they publicly subscribe to this or that ethical doctrine or to none at all. That is something that you cannot say aloud, or perhaps even think.

author: Henry David Thoreau
title: I have no doubt that it is a part of the destiny of the human race, in its gradual improvement, to leave off eating animals, as surely as the savage tribes have left off eating each other when they came in contact with the more civilized.

author: Edgar Allan Poe
title: I have no faith in human perfectibility. I think that human exertion will have no appreciable effect upon humanity. Man is now only more active -not more happy -nor more wise, than he was 6000 years ago.

author: Antoine de Saint-Exupery
title: I have no right, by anything I do or say, to demean a human being in his own eyes. What matters is not what I think of him; it is what he thinks of himself. To undermine a man's self-respect is a sin.

author: Baruch Spinoza
title: I have striven not to laugh at human actions, not to weep at them, nor to hate them, but to understand them.

author: Baruch Spinoza
title: I have taken great care not to deride, bewail, or execrate human actions, but to understand them.

author: Ann Veneman
title: I have to say that in this particular cow that we're dealing with, those parts of the cow were removed, and so we don't think there's any risk or very negligible risk to human health with this particular incident.

author: Armistead Maupin
title: I haven't lost faith in human nature and I haven't decided to be less compassionate to strangers.

author: Benjamin Tucker
title: I insist that there is nothing sacred in the life of an invader, and there is no valid principle of human society that forbids the invaded to protect themselves in whatever way they can.

author: Voltaire
title: I know of no great man except those who have rendered great services to the human race.

author: Paul Mccartney
title: I love to hear a choir. I love the humanity to see the faces of real people devoting themselves to a piece of music. I like the teamwork. It makes me feel optimistic about the human race when I see them cooperating like that.

author: Robert Burton
title: I may not here omit those two main plagues, and common dotages of human kind, wine and women, which have infatuated and besotted myriads of people. They go commonly together.

author: Margaret Mead
title: I must admit that I personally measure success in terms of the contributions an individual makes to her or his fellow human beings.

author: Winston Churchill
title: I must place on record my regret that the human race ever learned to fly.

author: Arthur Erickson
title: I plead for conservation of human culture, which is much more fragile than nature herself. We needn't destroy other cultures with the force of our own.

author: Thornton Wilder
title: I regard the theatre as the greatest of all art forms, the most immediate way in which a human being can share with another the sense of what it is to be a human being.

author: Buckminster Fuller
title: I set about fifty-five years ago (1927) to see what a penniless, unknown human individual with a dependent wife and newborn child might be able to do effectively on behalf of all humanity...

author: Alice James
title: I suppose one has a greater sense of intellectual degradation after an interview with a doctor than from any human experience.

author: Stephen Hawking
title: I think computer viruses should count as life … I think it says something about human nature that the only form of life we have created so far is purely destructive. We've created life in our own image.

author: Ann Veneman
title: I think it's important that, as a matter of course, the brain and spinal column were removed from this cow, and that would be the material that would cause concern in terms of human health. And therefore we're confident in the safety of the food supply.

author: Albert Ellis
title: I think it's unfair, but they have the right as fallible, screwed-up humans to be unfair; that's the human condition.

author: Jim Morrison
title: I think of myself as an intelligent, sensitive human with the soul of a clown, which always forces me to blow it at the most important times.

author: Bruce Greenwood
title: I think on some level, that's a fear that exists in everybody, that if we're tested, we won't make the courageous choice. We won't make the decision that would make us heroic. We make the decision that would reveal us to be all too human.

author: Andre Norton
title: I think the human race made a big mistake at the beginning of the industrial revolution, we leaped for the mechanical things, people need the use of their hands to feel creative.

author: David Mitchell
title: I think the story is the most ancient form of human entertainment.

author: William S. Burroughs
title: I think there are innumerable gods. What we on earth call God is a little tribal God who has made an awful mess. Certainly forces operating through human consciousness control events.

author: John F. Kennedy
title: I think this is the most extraordinary collection of talent, of human knowledge, that has ever been gathered together at the White House, with the possible exception of when Thomas Jefferson dined alone.

author: Angelina Grimke
title: I trust the time is coming, when the occupation of an instructor to children will be deemed the most honorable of human employment.

author: Antonio Tabucchi
title: I vividly remember the stories my grandfather told me about the carnage of the First World War, which people tend to forget was one of the worst massacres in human history.

author: J.G. Ballard
title: I wanted to rub the human race in its own vomit, and force it to look in the mirror.

author: Benazir Bhutto
title: I was brought up to believe that human beings are good, which is why it shocks me to the core when I see human beings behaving badly.

author: Kurt Vonnegut Jr
title: I was taught that the human brain was the crowning glory of evolution so far, but I think it's a very poor scheme for survival.

author: Diana Spencer Princess of Wales
title: I will fight for my children on any level so they can reach their potential as human beings and in their public duties.

author: Sir Walter Raleigh
title: I wish I loved the Human Race; I wish I loved its silly face; I wish I liked the way it walks; I wish I liked the way it talks; And when I'm introduced to one I wish I thought What Jolly Fun!

author: Beyonce Knowles
title: I'm a human being and I fall in love and sometimes I don't have control of every situation.

author: George Herbert Palmer
title: I'm defeated and I know it, if I meet any human being from whom I find myself unable to learn anything.

author: Malcolm X
title: I'm for truth, no matter who tells it. I'm for justice, no matter who it is for or against. I'm a human being, first and foremost, and as such I'm for whoever and whatever benefits humanity as a whole.

author: Bill Maris
title: I'm interested in the ideas that sound a little crazy, such as radical life extension, curing cancer, being able to create a simulation of the human brain and map every neuron.

author: Al Gore
title: I'm naturally an optimist, but my basis for hope is rooted in my understanding of human nature.,

author: Aileen Wuornos
title: I'm one who seriously hates human life and would kill again.

author: Beth Ditto
title: I've had a ton of fast-food jobs - it changes your approach to human interaction forever.

author: Bea Arthur
title: I've seen so many excellent actors - excellent actors - who, the minute they're told they're in a comedy, turn into God knows what - creatures from another planet! I mean they just... the voice changes, they don't look the same, it's like - it has no similarity to any living human being, do you know what I mean?

author: Marshall Mcluhan
title: Ideally, advertising aims at the goal of a programmed harmony among all human impulses and aspirations and endeavors. Using handicraft methods, it stretches out toward the ultimate electronic goal of a collective consciousness.

author: Anais Nin
title: If all of us acted in unison as I act individually there would be no wars and no poverty. I have made myself personally responsible for the fate of every human being who has come my way.

author: Albert Camus
title: If Christianity is pessimistic as to man, it is optimistic as to human destiny. Well, I can say that, pessimistic as to human destiny, I am optimistic as to man.

author: Mary Daly
title: If God is male, then male is God. The divine patriarch castrates women as long as he is allowed to live on in the human imagination.

author: Robert Conklin
title: If human beings are perceived as potentials rather than problems, as possessing strengths instead of weaknesses, as unlimited rather that dull and unresponsive, then they thrive and grow to their capabilities.

author: Myriam Miedzian
title: If human beings are to survive in a nuclear age, committing acts of violence may eventually have to become as embarrassing as urinating or defecating in public are today.

author: Aldous Huxley
title: If human beings were shown what they're really like, they'd either kill one another as vermin, or hang themselves.,

author: William Shakespeare
title: If I had a thousand sons, the first human principle I would teach them should be, to forswear thin potations.

author: Karl Wilhelm Von Humboldt
title: If it were not somewhat fanciful to suppose that every human excellence is presented, as it were, in one kind of being, we might believe that the whole treasure of morality and order is enshrined in the female character.

author: William James
title: If merely ''feeling good'' could decide, drunkenness would be the supremely valid human experience.

author: Aleksandr Solzjenitsyn
title: If one is forever cautious, can one remain a human being?

author: Albert Einstein
title: If one were to take that goal out of out of its religious form and look merely at its purely human side, one might state it perhaps thus: free and responsible development of the individual, so that he may place his powers freely and gladly in the service of all mankind.

author: Nadine Gordimer
title: If people would forget about utopia! When rationalism destroyed heaven and decided to set it up here on earth, that most terrible of all goals entered human ambition. It was clear there'd be no end to what people would be made to suffer for it.

author: Emile-Auguste Chartier
title: If religion is only human, and its form is man's form, it follows that everything in religion is true.

author: Seneca
title: If sensuality were happiness, beasts were happier than men; but human felicity is lodged in the soul, not in the flesh.

author: Carlton Fisk
title: If the human body recognized agony and frustration, people would never run marathons, have babies, or play baseball.

author: Emerson Pugh
title: If the human mind was simple enough to understand, we'd be too simple to understand it.

author: Winston Churchill
title: If the human race wishes to have a prolonged and indefinite period of material prosperity, they have only got to behave in a peaceful and helpful way toward one another

author: Alice Meynell
title: If there is a look of human eyes that tells of perpetual loneliness, so there is also the familiar look that is the sign of perpetual crowds.

author: Michael Harrington
title: If there is technological advance without social advance, there is, almost automatically, an increase in human misery, in impoverishment.

author: Honoré de Balzac
title: If those who are the enemies of innocent amusements had the direction of the world, they would take away the spring, and youth, the former from the year, the latter from human life.

author: Octavio Paz
title: If we are a metaphor of the universe, the human couple is the metaphor par excellence, the point of intersection of all forces and the seed of all forms. The couple is time recaptured, the return to the time before time.

author: Margaret Mead
title: If we are to achieve a richer culture, rich in contrasting values, we must recognize the whole gamut of human potentialities, and so weave a less arbitrary social fabric, one in which each diverse human gift will find a fitting place.

author: Bayard Rustin
title: If we desire a society in which men are brothers, then we must act towards one another with brotherhood. If we can build such a society, then we would have achieved the ultimate goal of human freedom.

author: Karl Wilhelm Von Humboldt
title: If we glance at the most important revolutions in history, we see at once that the greatest number of these originated in the periodical revolutions of the human mind.

author: George Eliot
title: If we had a keen vision and feeling of all ordinary human life, it would be like hearing the grass grow and the squirrel's heart beat, and we should die of that roar which lies on the other side of silence. As it is, the best of us walk about well wadded with stupidity.

author: Freeman Dyson
title: If we had a reliable way to label our toys good and bad, it would be easy to regulate technology wisely. But we can rarely see far enough ahead to know which road leads to damnation. Whoever concerns himself with big technology, either to push it forward or to stop it, is gambling in human lives.

author: Eleanor Roosevelt
title: If we want a free and peaceful world, if we want to make the deserts bloom and man grow to greater dignity as a human being-we can do it.

author: Carolyn See
title: If you are in any way squeamish or genteel, skip 'Gillespie and I.' If you'd like to know a little more about the seamy side of the human condition, by all means, pick this one up.

author: Barry Commoner
title: If you ask what you are going to do about global warming, the only rational answer is to change the way in which we do transportation, energy production, agriculture and a good deal of manufacturing. The problem originates in human activity in the form of the production of goods.

author: George Orwell
title: If you can feel that staying human is worth while, even when it can't have any practical result whatsoever, you've beaten them.

author: Jerome K. Jerome
title: If you desire to drain to the dregs the fullest cup of scorn and hatred that a fellow human being can pour out for you, let a young mother hear you call dear baby ''it.''

author: C. Wright Mills
title: If you do not specify and confront real issues, what you say will surely obscure them. If you do not embody controversy, what you say will be an acceptance of the drift to the coming human hell.

author: Bill Goldberg
title: If you don't want to investigate what you're passing judgment on, then it's your fault. And I believe that if people investigate Goldberg as a human being, I'm not such a bad guy.

author: Billy Joel
title: If you make music for the human needs you have within yourself, then you do it for all humans who need the same things. You enrich humanity with the profound expression of these feelings.

author: Buzz Osborne
title: If you take a band like Nirvana, their biggest hits are structurally the same as even a hair metal band's biggest hits. The structure's not different - the attitude was different. Except it really wasn't. It seemed a little more human.

author: George Orwell
title: If you want a vision of the future, imagine a boot stamping on a human face - forever.

author: Gabriel Heatter
title: If you were happy every day of your life you wouldn't be a human being, you'd be a game show host.

author: Shashi Tharoor
title: Im not a techno-determinist. I believe we need to improve our existing human resources, and technology can only be a complement.

author: Bill Flores
title: Imagine having all of your freedoms taken away, being forced to work against your will, and constantly living under the threat of violence - in short, being forced to live as a slave. Sadly, this situation is a reality for millions of children, women, and men each year as part of the global human trafficking industry.

author: Euripides
title: Impudence is the worst of all human diseases.

author: Barney Frank
title: In a free society a large degree of human activity is none of the government's business. We should make criminal what's going to hurt other people and other than that we should leave it to people to make their own choices.

author: Bob Barr
title: In a single generation, the Internet has given to virtually every person on the face of the earth the ability to communicate with fellow human beings on virtually any topic, at any time, and in every nook and cranny on the globe. This magnificent invention has done this without succumbing to government control.

author: Stephen Hawking
title: In a world that is in chaos politically, socially and environmentally, how can the human race sustain another 100 years?

author: James Allen
title: In all human affairs there are efforts, and there are results, and the strength of effort is the measure of the results.

author: Bryant H. McGill
title: In all known time there has never been a greater monster or miracle than the human being.

author: Harriet Beecher Stowe
title: In all ranks of life the human heart yearns for the beautiful; and the beautiful things that God makes are his gift to all alike.

author: Quentin Crisp
title: In an expanding universe, time is on the side of the outcast. Those who once inhabited the suburbs of human contempt find that without changing their address they eventually live in the metropolis.

author: Ambrose Bierce
title: In each human heart are a tiger, a pig, an ass and a nightingale. Diversity of character is due to their unequal activity.

author: George Santayana
title: In endowing us with memory, nature has revealed to us a truth utterly unimaginable to the unreflective creation, the truth of immortality. The most ideal human passion is love, which is also the most absolute and animal and one of the most ephemeral.

author: Carl Sagan
title: In every country, we should be teaching our children the scientific method and the reasons for a Bill of Rights. With it comes a certain decency, humility and community spirit. In the demon-haunted world that we inhabit by virtue of being human, this may be all that stands between us and the enveloping darkness.

author: Albert Schweitzer
title: In everyone's life, at some time, our inner fire goes out. It is then burst into flame by an encounter with another human being. We should all be thankful for those people who rekindle the inner spirit.

author: Bruce Dern
title: In Hitchcock's eyes the movement was dramatic, not the acting. When he wanted the audience to be moved, he moved the camera. He was a subtle human being, and he was also the best director I have ever worked with.

author: Plutarch
title: In human life there is constant change of fortune; and it is unreasonable to expect an exemption from the common fate. Life itself decays, and all things are daily changing.

author: Elwyn Brooks White
title: In middle life, the human back is spoiling for a technical knockout and will use the flimsiest excuse, even a sneeze, to fall apart.

author: Barbara de Angelis
title: In order to experience everyday spirituality, we need to remember that we are spiritual beings spending some time in a human body.

author: Adrienne Rich
title: In order to live a fully human life we require not only control of our bodies (though control is a prerequisite); we must touch the unity and resonance of our physicality, our bond with the natural order, the corporeal grounds of our intelligence.

author: Richard Whately
title: In our judgment of human transactions, the law of optics is reversed, we see most dimly the objects which are close around us.

author: Bruce Lipton
title: In reality, a cell is a biological mini-me compared to the human body. A cell has every biological system that you have.

author: Baz Luhrmann
title: In terms of the mechanics of story, myth is an intriguing one because we didn't make myth up; myth is an imprinture of the human condition.

author: Alfred Marshall
title: In the absence of any short term in common use to represent all desirable things, or things that satisfy human wants, we may use the term Goods for that purpose.

author: Thomas Szasz
title: In the animal kingdom, the rule is, eat or be eaten; in the human kingdom, define or be defined.

author: Alexander Walker
title: In the days of Gary Cooper, James Stewart etc, film stars personified the better aspects of human nature.

author: Aberjhani
title: In the face of a world where economic hardships often ground the best of the human spirit into the worst, love provided a pathway into hidden chambers of the spirit where nobility and compassion might be salvaged, resurrected, and made stronger.

author: Alexander Hamilton
title: In the general course of human nature, A power over a man's subsistence amounts to a power over his will.

author: Francois de la Rochefoucauld
title: In the human heart new passions are forever being born; the overthrow of one almost always means the rise of another.

author: Alfred Hitchcock
title: In the old days villains had moustaches and kicked the dog. Audiences are smarter today. They don't want their villain to be thrown at them with green limelight on his face. They want an ordinary human being with failings.

author: Abraham Kuyper
title: In the total expanse of human life there is not a single square inch of which the Christ, who alone is sovereign, does not declare, 'That is mine!'.

author: Emma Goldman
title: In the true sense one's native land, with its background of tradition, early impressions, reminiscences and other things dear to one, is not enough to make sensitive human beings feel at home.

author: Carl von Clausewitz
title: In the whole range of human activities, war most closely resembles a game of cards.

author: H. A. Kramers
title: In the world of human thought generally, and in physical science particularly, the most important and fruitful concepts are those to which it is impossible to attach a well-defined meaning.

author: Bernard Le Bovier de Fontenelle
title: In vain we shall penetrate more and more deeply the secrets of the structure of the human body, we shall not dupe nature; we shall die as usual.

author: Haniel Long
title: In youth the human body drew me and was the object of my secret and natural dreams. But body after body has taken away from me that sensual phosphorescence which my youth delighted in. Within me is no disturbing interplay now, but only the steady currents of adaptation and of sympathy.

author: Robert Browning
title: Inscribe all human effort with one word, artistry's haunting curse, the Incomplete!

author: Charles Horton Cooley
title: Institutions - government, churches, industries, and the like - have properly no other function than to contribute to human freedom; and in so far as they fail, on the whole, to perform this function, they are wrong and need reconstruction.

author: Philip Roth
title: Is an intelligent human being likely to be much more than a large-scale manufacturer of misunderstanding?

author: Buzz Aldrin
title: Is the destiny of the human species to sit back and play with our mouse and computer and imagine, fantasize?

author: Søren Kierkegaard
title: It belongs to the imperfection of everything human that man can only attain his desire by passing through its opposite.

author: Bryan Magee
title: It could be that the total scenario for human beings is an insoluble mystery until we die, followed by nothing at all.

author: Benjamin Disraeli
title: It destroys one's nerves to be amiable every day to the same human being.

author: Thomas Malthus
title: It has appeared that from the inevitable laws of our nature, some human beings must suffer from want. These are the unhappy persons who, in the great lottery of life, have drawn a blank.

author: Bette Davis
title: It has been my experience that one cannot, in any shape or form, depend on human relations for lasting reward. It is only work that truly satisfies.

author: Lord George Byron
title: It has been said that the immortality of the soul is a ''grand peut-''tre'' - but still it is a grand one. Everybody clings to it -the stupidest, and dullest, and wickedest of human bipeds is still persuaded that he is immortal.

author: Anthony de Mello
title: It is a great mystery that though the human heart longs for Truth, in which alone it finds liberation and delight, the first reaction of human beings to Truth is one of hostility and fear!

author: Charles Dickens
title: It is a pleasant thing to reflect upon, and furnishes a complete answer to those who contend for the gradual degeneration of the human species, that every baby born into the world is a finer one than the last.

author: Tacitus
title: It is a weakness of your human nature to hate those whom you have wronged.

author: G. C. Lichtenberg
title: It is almost everywhere the case that soon after it is begotten the greater part of human wisdom is laid to rest in repositories.

author: Anatole France
title: It is almost systematically to constitute a natural moral law. Nature has no principles. She furnishes us with no reason to believe that human life is to be respected. Nature, in her indifference, makes no difference between right and wrong.

author: David Hume
title: It is an absurdity to believe that the Deity has human passions, and one of the lowest of human passions, a restless appetite for applause.

author: Voltaire
title: It is an infantile superstition of the human spirit that virginity would be thought a virtue and not the barrier that separates ignorance from knowledge.

author: Margaret Fuller
title: It is astonishing what force, purity, and wisdom it requires for a human being to keep clear of falsehoods.

author: Freeman Dyson
title: It is characteristic of all deep human problems that they are not to be approached without some humor and some bewilderment.

author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow
title: It is curious to note the old sea-margins of human thought! Each subsiding century reveals some new mystery; we build where monsters used to hide themselves.

author: Marianne Moore
title: It is human nature to stand in the middle of a thing.

author: Anatole France
title: It is human nature to think wisely and act foolishly.

author: Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe
title: It is in human nature to relax, when not compelled by personal advantage or disadvantage.

author: Hannah Arendt
title: It is in the very nature of things human that every act that has once made its appearance and has been recorded in the history of mankind stays with mankind as a potentiality long after its actuality has become a thing of the past.

author: Charlotte Brontë
title: It is in vain to say human beings ought to be satisfied with tranquillity: they must have action; and they will make it if they cannot find it.

author: Ben Stein
title: It is inevitable that some defeat will enter even the most victorious life. The human spirit is never finished when it is defeated... it is finished when it surrenders.

author: Joyce Carol Oates
title: It is not her body that he wants but it is only through her body that he can take possession of another human being, so he must labor upon her body, he must enter her body, to make his claim.

author: Denis Diderot
title: It is not human nature we should accuse but the despicable conventions that pervert it.

author: Bill Bryson
title: It is not true that the English invented cricket as a way of making all other human endeavours look interesting and lively; that was merely an unintended side effect. I don't wish to denigrate a sport that is enjoyed by millions, some of them awake and facing the right way, but it is an odd game.

author: Carl Sagan
title: It is of interest to note that while some dolphins are reported to have learned English -- up to fifty words used in correct context -- no human being has been reported to have learned dolphinese.

author: Aung San Suu Kyi
title: It is often in the name of cultural integrity as well as social stability and national security that democratic reforms based on human rights are resisted by authoritarian governments.

author: Voltaire
title: It is one of the superstitions of the human mind to have imagined that virginity could be a virtue.

author: Arthur Eddington
title: It is one thing for the human mind to extract from the phenomena of nature the laws which it has itself put into them; it may be a far harder thing to extract laws over which it has no control.

author: C. S. Lewis
title: It is only when you are asked to believe in Reason coming from non-reason that you must cry Halt. Human minds. They do not come from nowhere.

author: H.G. Wells
title: It is possible to believe that all the past is but the beginning of a beginning, and that all that is and has been is but the twilight of the dawn. It is possible to believe that all the human mind has ever accomplished is but the dream before the awakening.

author: Raymond Chandler
title: It is pretty obvious that the debasement of the human mind caused by a constant flow of fraudulent advertising is no trivial thing. There is more than one way to conquer a country.

author: Benjamin Banneker
title: It is the indispensable duty of those, who maintain for themselves the rights of human nature, and who possess the obligations of Christianity, to extend their power and influence to the relief of every part of the human race...

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: It is the privilege of any human work which is well done to invest the doer with a certain haughtiness. He can well afford not to conciliate, whose faithful work will answer for him.

author: Aleksandr Solzjenitsyn
title: It is time in the West to defend not so much human rights as human obligations.

author: Andrew Cohen
title: It is true that women tend to be more identified with their bodies because in this crazy world, both men and women measure women's value as human beings in relationship to their physical appearance.

author: Charlotte Brontë
title: It is vain to say human beings ought to be satisfied with tranquillity: they must have action; and they will make it if they cannot find it.

author: Joseph Conrad
title: It is very difficult to be wholly joyous or wholly sad on this earth. The comic, when it is human, soon takes upon itself a face of pain; and some of our grieves... have their source in weaknesses which must be recognized with smiling compassion as the common inheritance of us all.

author: Antonio Guterres
title: It is, for me, clear that the world needs a United States that is engaged in security issues, in development issues, in human rights issues. The contribution of the United States for global affairs is absolutely crucial. And the cooperation with the U.N. is very important from our perspective.

author: Breyten Breytenbach
title: It may be an extreme example brought about by abnormal circumstances - but the criteria of human rights kick in, surely, precisely when the conditions are extreme and the situation is abnormal.

author: Robert Lynd
title: It may be that all games are silly. But then, so are human beings.

author: Barry Commoner
title: It reflects a prevailing myth that production technology is no more amenable to human judgment or social interests than the laws of thermodynamics, atomic structure or biological inheritance.

author: Alfred Loisy
title: It seems obvious to me that the notion of God has never been anything but a kind of ideal projection, a reflection upward of the human personality, and that theology never has been and never can be anything but a more and more purified mythology.

author: Barbara Ehrenreich
title: It seems to me that there must be an ecological limit to the number of paper pushers the earth can sustain, and that human civilization will collapse when the number of, say, tax lawyers exceeds the world's total population of farmers, weavers, fisherpersons, and pediatric nurses.

author: Bruce Cockburn
title: It sounds strange to say it, but you can be in a war zone and have a lot of fun. Even though war is essentially pain on all sides, human beings have the capacity to enjoy themselves. The soldiers are mostly young people, full of enthusiasm and energy, and that's an exciting thing for an old guy like me.

author: Albert Einstein
title: It stands to the everlasting credit of science that by acting on the human mind it has overcome man's insecurity before himself and before nature.

author: Eric Hoffer
title: It still holds true that man is most uniquely human when he turns obstacles into opportunities.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: It were a real increase of human happiness, could all young men from the age of nineteen be covered under barrels, or rendered otherwise invisible; and there left to follow their lawful studies and callings, till they emerged, sadder and wiser, at the age of twenty-five.

author: Anais Nin
title: It's all right for a woman to be, above all, human. I am a woman first of all.

author: Will Rogers
title: It's great to be great, but it's greater to be human.

author: Philip Roth
title: It's human to have a secret, but it's just as human to reveal it sooner or later.

author: George Orwell
title: It's not so much staying alive, it's staying human that's important. What counts is that we don't betray each other.

author: Angela Davis
title: Jails and prisons are designed to break human beings, to convert the population into specimens in a zoo - obedient to our keepers, but dangerous to each other.

author: Aldous Huxley
title: Jehovah, Allah, the Trinity, Jesus, Buddha, are names for a great variety of human virtues, human mystical experiences human remorses, human compensatory fantasies, human terrors, human cruelties. If all men were alike, all the world would worship the same God.

author: Victor Hugo
title: Jesus wept; Voltaire smiled. From that divine tear and from that human smile is derived the grace of present civilization.

author: Bobby Keys
title: John Lennon, who was a good friend of mine, he had one of the best senses of humor of any human being. And Keith Richards, fantastic sense of humor. They were smart, sharp. They had their own thoughts on matters.

author: Rollo May
title: Joy, rather than happiness, is the goal of life, for joy is the emotion which accompanies our fulfilling our natures as human beings. It is based on the experience of one's identity as a being of worth and dignity.

author: Elie Wiesel
title: Just as despair can come to one only from other human beings, hope, too, can be given to one only by other human beings.

author: Erich Fromm
title: Just as love is an orientation which refers to all objects and is incompatible with the restriction to one object, so is reason a human faculty which must embrace the whole of the world with which man is confronted.

author: Regis McKenna
title: Just as one year in a dog's life is equivalent to seven years in a human life, one year in the high-technology business is like seven years in any other industry.

author: Anne Grant
title: Just as the body goes into shock after a physical trauma, so does the human psyche go into shock after the impact of a major loss.

author: Buddha
title: Just as treasures are uncovered from the earth, so virtue appears from good deeds, and wisdom appears from a pure and peaceful mind. To walk safely through the maze of human life, one needs the light of wisdom and the guidance of virtue.

author: A. Philip Randolph
title: Justice is never given; it is exacted and the struggle must be continuous for freedom is never a final fact, but a continuing evolving process to higher and higher levels of human, social, economic, political and religious relationship.

author: Bobby Fischer
title: Kasparov is a gangster, he is a disgrace to chess, he is a disgrace to the human race. He is not something Russia should be proud of. He should join Khodorkovsky in prison. He has committed a terrible fraud with all these prearranged games and matches.

author: Barbara Grizzuti Harrison
title: Kindness and intelligence don't always deliver us from the pitfalls and traps: there are always failures of love, of will, of imagination. There is no way to take the danger out of human relationships.

author: James Redfield
title: Knowing our personal mission further enhances the flow of mysterious coincidences as we are guided toward our destinies. First we have a question, then dreams, daydreams, and intuitions lead us toward the answers, which usually are synchronistically provided by the wisdom of another human being.

author: Francis Bacon
title:
Knowledge and human power are synonymous.,
,

author: Daniel Webster
title: Knowledge is the only fountain both of love and the principles of human liberty.

author: Mary McCarthy
title: Labor is work that leaves no trace behind it when it is finished, or if it does, as in the case of the tilled field, this product of human activity requires still more labor, incessant, tireless labor, to maintain its identity as a ''work'' of man.

author: Carol Windley
title: Language and written language are the only real way we have to see inside another person's thoughts and to know what makes another person human. Without writing, we just wouldn't have that kind of access.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Language is a city to the building of which every human being brought a stone.

author: Claude Lévi-Strauss
title: Language is a form of human reason, which has its internal logic of which man knows nothing.

author: Russell Hoban
title: Language is an archeological vehicle... the language we speak is a whole palimpsest of human effort and history.

author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge
title: Language is the armory of the human mind, and at once contains the trophies of its past and the weapons of its future conquests.

author: Victor Hugo
title: Laughter is the sun that drives winter from the human face.

author: Walter Lippmann
title: Let a human being throw the energies of his soul into the making of something, and the instinct of workmanship will take care of his honesty.

author: Nelson Mandela
title: Let freedom reign. The sun never set on so glorious a human achievement.

author: Herman Melville
title: Let me look into a human eye; it is better than to gaze into sea or sky; better than to gaze upon God.

author: Alexander Pope
title: Let sinful bachelors their woes deplore; full well they merit all they feel, and more: unaw by precepts, human or divine, like birds and beasts, promiscuously they join.

author: Bob Parsons
title: Let's be honest. There's not a business anywhere that is without problems. Business is complicated and imperfect. Every business everywhere is staffed with imperfect human beings and exists by providing a product or service to other imperfect human beings.

author: C. S. Lewis
title: Let's pray that the human race never escapes from Earth to spread its iniquity elsewhere.

author: Thomas Sowell
title: Liberalism is totalitarianism with a human face.,

author: Imelda Marcos
title: Life is not a matter of place, things or comfort; rather, it concerns the basic human rights of family, country, justice and human dignity.

author: Carlo Ratti
title: Like a tracer running through the veins of the city, networks of air quality sensors attached to bikes can help measure an individual's exposure to pollution and draw a dynamic map of the urban air on a human scale, as in the case of the Copenhagen Wheel developed by new startup Superpedestrian.

author: Elizabeth Janeway
title: Like their personal lives, women's history is fragmented, interrupted; a shadow history of human beings whose existence has been shaped by the efforts and the demands of others.

author: Octavio Paz
title: Literature is the expression of a feeling of deprivation, a recourse against a sense of something missing. But the contrary is also true: language is what makes us human. It is a recourse against the meaningless noise and silence of nature and history.

author: Lionel Trilling
title: Literature is the human activity that make the fullest and most precise account of variousness, possibility, complexity, and difficulty.

author: Salman Rushdie
title: Literature is where I go to explore the highest and lowest places in human society and in the human spirit, where I hope to find not absolute truth but the truth of the tale, of the imagination and of the heart.

author: Ambrose Bierce
title: Logic, n. The art of thinking and reasoning in strict accordance with the limitations and incapacities of the human misunderstanding.

author: Ambrose Bierce
title: Logic: The art of thinking and reasoning in strict accordance with the limitations and incapacities of the human misunderstanding.

author: Bill Parcells
title: Look, coaching is about human interaction and trying to know your players. Any coach would tell you that. I'm no different.

author: Robert Hayden
title: Love and death are the two great hinges on which all human sympathies turn.

author: Aldous Huxley
title: Love is as necessary to human beings as food and shelter; [but] without intelligence, ... love is impotent and freedom unattainable.

author: Ann Landers
title: Love is friendship that has caught fire. It is quiet understanding, mutual confidence, sharing and forgiving. It is loyalty through good and bad times. It settles for less than perfection and makes allowances for human weaknesses.

author: Erich Fromm
title: Love is the only sane and satisfactory answer to the problem of human existence.

author: Victor Frankel
title: Love is the only way to grasp another human being in the innermost core of his personality.

author: Aleister Crowley
title: Love stories are only fit for the solace of people in the insanity of puberty. No healthy adult human being can really care whether so-and-so does or does not succeed in satisfying his physiological uneasiness by the aid of some particular person or not.

title: Love, by its very nature, is unworldly, and it is for this reason rather than its rarity that it is not only apolitical but anti-political, perhaps the most powerful of all anti-political human forces.

author: Mark Twain
title: Loyalty to petrified opinions never yet broke a chain or freed a human soul in this world - and never will.

author: Bertrand Russell
title: Machines deprive us of two things which are certainly important ingredients of human happiness, namely, spontaneity and variety.

author: André Malraux
title: Man knows that the world is not made on a human scale; and he wishes that it were.

author: Adam Clarke
title: Man may be considered as having a twofold origin - natural, which is common and the same to all - patronymic, which belongs to the various families of which the whole human race is composed.

author: Bernard Williams
title: Man never made any material as resilient as the human spirit.

author: Antonio Machado
title: Man would be otherwise. That is the essence of the specifically human.

author: Erich Fromm
title: Man's biological weakness is the condition of human culture.

title: Mankind must evolve for all human conflict a method which rejects revenge, aggression, and retaliation. The foundation of such a method is love.

author: Samuel P. Huntington
title: Many more people in the world are concerned with sports than with human rights.

author: B. F. Skinner
title: Many social practices essential to the welfare of the species involve the control of one person by another, and no one can suppress them who has any concern for human achievements.

author: Barry McGuire
title: Marches alone won't bring integration when human respect is disintegratin'

author: Vicki Baum
title: Marriage always demands the greatest understanding of the art of insincerity possible between two human beings.

author: Robert F. Kennedy
title: Martin Luther King dedicated his life to love and to justice between fellow human beings. ,

author: W. H. Auden
title: May it not be that, just as we have to have faith in Him, God has to have faith in us and, considering the history of the human race so far, may it not be that ''faith'' is even more difficult for Him than it is for us?

author: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh
title: Meditation is just a strategy to take away your personality, your thoughts, your mind, your identity with the body, and leave you absolutely alone inside, just a living fire. And once you have found your living fire, you will know all the joys and all the ecstasies that human consciousness is capable of.

author: Carl von Clausewitz
title: Men are always more inclined to pitch their estimate of the enemy's strength too high than too low, such is human nature.

author: Andrea Dworkin
title: Men renounce whatever they have in common with women so as to experience no commonality with women; and what is left, according to men, is one piece of flesh a few inches long, the penis. The penis is sensate; the penis is the man; the man is human; the penis signifies humanity.

author: Virginia Woolf
title: Methinks the human method of expression by sound of tongue is very elementary, and ought to be substituted for some ingenious invention which should be able to give vent to at least six coherent sentences at once.

author: Ban Kimoon
title: Migration is an expression of the human aspiration for dignity, safety and a better future. It is part of the social fabric, part of our very make-up as a human family.

author: Ansel Adams

author: Henry Ward Beecher

author: Al Franken
title: Mistakes are a part of being human. Appreciate your mistakes for what they are: precious life lessons that can only be learned the hard way. Unless it's a fatal mistake, which, at least, others can learn from.

author: Benjamin Disraeli
title: Moderation is the center wherein all philosophies, both human and divine, meet.

author: Ivan Illich
title: Modern medicine is a negation of health. It isn't organized to serve human health, but only itself, as an institution. It makes more people sick than it heals.

author: Arthur Schopenhauer

author: Henry Louis Mencken
title: Morality is the theory that every human act must be either right or wrong, and that 99 % of them are wrong.,

author: George Eliot
title: More helpful than all wisdom is one draught of simple human pity that will not forsake us.

author: Gabriel Heatter
title: More power than all the success slogans ever penned by human hand is the realization for every man that he has but one boss. That boss is the man - he - himself.

author: Kofi Annan

author: Aldous Huxley
title: Most human beings have an almost infinite capacity for taking things for granted.

author: James A. Garfield
title: Most human organizations that fall short of their goals do so not because of stupidity or faulty doctrines, but because of internal decay and rigidification. They grow stiff in the joints. They get in a rut. They go to seed.

author: Bo Bennett
title: Most of us are consumed with our own thoughts and desires and are not always thinking about what other people may want. This is not necessarily being egocentric; it is just being human.

author: Camille Paglia
title: Most of western culture is a distortion of reality. But reality should be distorted; that is, imaginatively amended. The Buddhist acquiescence to nature is neither accurate about nature nor just to human potential.

author: Suzanne Lafollette
title: Most people, no doubt, when they espouse human rights, make their own mental reservations about the proper application of the word ''human.''

author: Zig Ziglar
title: Motivation is the fuel, necessary to keep the human engine running.

author: Carl Sagan
title: Much of human history can, I think, be described as a gradual and sometimes painful liberation from provincialism, the emerging awareness that there is more to the world than was generally believed by our ancestors.

author: Lewis Thomas
title: Music is the effort we make to explain to ourselves how our brains work. We listen to Bach transfixed because this is listening to a human mind.

author: Lawrence Durrell
title: Music was invented to confirm human loneliness.

author: Antonia Fraser
title: My advantage as a woman and a human being has been in having a mother who believed strongly in women's education. She was an early undergraduate at Oxford, and her own mother was a doctor.

author: J.G. Ballard
title: My brief stay at the hospital had already convinced me that the medical profession was an open door to anyone nursing a grudge against the human race.

author: Beeban Kidron
title: My children know not to shout before Mummy has warmed herself into something human with her coffee.

author: Ursula K. Le Guin
title: My imagination makes me human and makes me a fool; it gives me all the world and exiles me from it.

author: A. E. van Vogt
title: My theory was that what I had to do was make a study of human behavior.

author: David Herbert Lawrence
title: Myth is an attempt to narrate a whole human experience, of which the purpose is too deep, going too deep in the blood and soul, for mental explanation or description.

author: Bernard Marcus
title: Nanotechnology in medicine is going to have a major impact on the survival of the human race.

author: Barbara Ehrenreich
title: Natural selection, as it has operated in human history, favors not only the clever but the murderous.

author: Adlai E. Stevenson II
title: Nature is indifferent to the survival of the human species, including Americans.

author: Lao-Tzu
title: Nature is not human hearted.

author: Luigi Pirandello
title: Nature uses human imagination to lift her work of creation to even higher levels.

author: William Pitt
title: Necessity is the plea for every infringement of human freedom. It is the argument of tyrants; it is the creed of slaves.

author: Edwin Hubbel Chapin
title: Never does the human soul appear so strong and noble as when it forgoes revenge and dares to forgive an injury.

author: Winston Churchill
title: Never in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so few.

author: Hosea Ballou
title: Never let your zeal outrun your charity. The former is but human, the latter is divine.

author: Marquis de Sade
title: Never lose sight of the fact that all human felicity lies in man's imagination, and that he cannot think to attain it unless he heeds all his caprices. The most fortunate of persons is he who has the most means to satisfy his vagaries.

author: Robert A. Heinlein
title: Never underestimate the power of human stupidity.,

author: Barry Humphries
title: New Zealand is a country of thirty thousand million sheep, three million of whom think they are human.

author: William Howard Taft
title: Next to the right of liberty, the right of property is the most important individual right guaranteed by the Constitution and the one which, united with that of personal liberty, has contributed more to the growth of civilization than any other institution established by the human race.

author: Max Lerner
title: Next to the striking of fire and the discovery of the wheel, the greatest triumph of what we call civilization was the domestication of the human male.

author: George Orwell
title: No advance in wealth, no softening of manners, no reform or revolution has ever brought human equality a millimeter nearer.,

author: Edward Bulwer-Lytton
title: No author ever drew a character consistent to human nature, but he was forced to ascribe to it many inconsistencies.

author: George Orwell
title: No doubt alcohol, tobacco, and so forth, are things that a saint must avoid; but sainthood is also a thing that human beings must avoid.

author: A. A. Milne
title: No doubt Jack the Ripper excused himself on the grounds that it was human nature.

author: Seneca
title: No evil propensity of the human heart is so powerful that it may mot be subdued by discipline.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: No government power can be abused long. Mankind will not bear it. There is a remedy in human nature against tyranny, that will keep us safe under every form of government.

author: Annie Jump Cannon
title: No greater problem is presented to the human mind.

author: Robert Lynd
title: No human being believes that any other human being has a right to be in bed when he himself is up.

author: José Saramago
title: No human being can achieve all he or she desires in this life except in dreams, so good night all.

author: W. H. Auden
title: No human being is innocent, but there is a class of innocent human actions called Games.

author: John Ruskin
title: No human being, however great, or powerful, was ever so free as a fish.

author: E. M. Cioran
title: No human beings more dangerous than those who have suffered for a belief: the great persecutors are recruited from the martyrs not quite beheaded. Far from diminishing the appetite for power, suffering exasperates it.

author: Elie Wiesel
title: No human race is superior; no religious faith is inferior. All collective judgments are wrong. Only racists make them.

author: John Steinbeck
title: No man really knows about other human beings. The best he can do is to suppose that they are like himself.,

author: Charles Horton Cooley
title: No matter what a man does, he is not fully sane or human unless there is a spirit of freedom in him, a soul unconfined by purpose and larger than the practicable world.

author: Peace Pilgrim
title: No one can find inner peace except by working, not in a self- centered way, but for the whole human family.

author: Marguerite Duras
title: No other human being, no woman, no poem or music, book or painting can replace alcohol in its power to give man the illusion of real creation.

author: Helen Keller
title: No pessimist ever discovered the secrets of the stars, or sailed to an uncharted land, or opened a new heaven to the human spirit.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: No place affords a more striking conviction of the vanity of human hopes than a public library.

author: Don DeLillo
title: No sense of the irony of human experience, that we are the highest form of life on earth, and yet ineffably sad because we know what no other animal knows, that we must die.

author: Alfred de Vigny
title: No writer, no matter how gifted, immortalizes himself unless he has crystallized into expressive and original phrase the eternal sentiments and yearnings of the human heart.

author: Barbra Streisand
title: Nobody on this earth has the right to tell anyone that their love for another human being is morally wrong.

author: Lydia M. Child
title: None speak of the bravery, the might, or the intellect of Jesus; but the devil is always imagined as a being of acute intellect, political cunning, and the fiercest courage. These universal and instinctive tendencies of the human mind reveal much.

author: Edwin Hubbel Chapin
title: Not in achievement, but in endurance, of the human soul, does it show its divine grandeur and its alliance with the infinite.

author: Barry Cornwall
title: Not the rich viol, trump, cymbal, nor horn, Guitar, nor cittern, nor the pining flute, Are half so sweet as tender human words.

author: Friedrich von Schiller
title: Not without a shudder may the human hand reach into the mysterious urn of destiny.

author: Benjamin Disraeli
title: Nothing can resist the human will that will stake even its existence on its stated purpose.

author: Benjamin Disraeli
title: Nothing can withstand the power of the human will if it is willing to stake its very existence to the extent of its purpose.

author: John Berger
title: Nothing in the nature around us is evil. This needs to be repeated since one of the human ways of talking oneself into inhuman acts is to cite the supposed cruelty of nature.

author: Marcus Tullius Cicero
title: Nothing is more noble, nothing more venerable than fidelity. Faithfulness and truth are the most sacred excellences and endowments of the human mind.

author: Alexis de Tocqueville
title: Nothing seems at first sight less important than the outward form of human actions, yet there is nothing upon which men set more store: they grow used to everything except to living in a society which has not their own manners.

author: Albert Einstein
title: Nothing will benefit human health and increase the chances for survival of life on Earth as much as the evolution to a vegetarian diet

author: Desiderius Erasmus
title: Now I believe I can hear the philosophers protesting that it can only be misery to live in folly, illusion, deception and ignorance, but it isn't - it's human.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Now that we have learned to fly the air like birds, swim under water like fish, we lack one thing - to learn to live on earth as human beings.

author: William S. Burroughs
title: Now what sort of man or woman or monster would stroke a centipede I have ever seen? ''And here is my good big centipede!'' If such a man exists, I say kill him without more ado. He is a traitor to the human race.

author: Barry Cornwall
title: O human beauty, what a dream art thou, that we should cast our life and hopes away on thee!

author: Booker T. Washington
title: Of all forms of slavery there is none that is so harmful and degrading as that form of slavery which tempts one human being to hate another by reason of his race or color. One man cannot hold another man down in the ditch without remaining down in the ditch with him.

author: Marcus Tullius Cicero
title: Of all nature's gifts to the human race, what is sweeter to a man than his children?

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Of all the damnable waste of human life that ever was invented, clerking is the worst.

author: Anna Garlin Spencer
title: Of all the wastes of human ignorance perhaps the most extravagant and costly to human growth has been the waste of the distinctive powers of womanhood after the child-bearing age.

author: Boris Pasternak
title: Oh, how one wishes sometimes to escape from the meaningless dullness of human eloquence, from all those sublime phrases, to take refuge in nature, apparently so inarticulate, or in the wordlessness of long grinding labor, of sound sleep, of true music, or of a human understanding, rendered speechless by emotion!

author: Caroline Knapp
title: On the broad spectrum of solitude, I lean toward the extreme end: I work alone, as well as live alone, so I can pass an entire day without uttering so much as a hello to another human being. Sometimes a day's conversation consists of only five words, uttered at the local Starbucks: 'Large coffee with milk, please.'

author: George Orwell
title: On the whole human beings want to be good, but not to good and not quite all the time.

author: George Orwell
title: On the whole, human beings want to be good, but not too good, and not quite all the time.

author: John Berger
title: One can say of language that it is potentially the only human home, the only dwelling place that cannot be hostile to man.

author: Jean Anouilh
title: One cannot weep for the entire world, it is beyond human strength. One must choose.

author: Jean Rostand
title: One must either take an interest in the human situation or else parade before the void.

author: May Sarton
title: One must think like a hero to behave like a merely decent human being.

author: Anna Julia Cooper
title: One needs occasionally to stand aside from the hum and rush of human interests and passions to hear the voices of God.

author: Salman Rushdie
title: One of the extraordinary things about human events is that the unthinkable becomes thinkable.

author: Charles Horton Cooley
title: One of the great reasons for the popularity of strikes is that they give the suppressed self a sense of power. For once the human tool knows itself a man, able to stand up and speak a word or strike a blow.

author: Walter Bagehot
title: One of the greatest pains to human nature is the pain of a new idea.

author: Aldous Huxley
title: One of the many reasons for the bewildering and tragic character of human existence is the fact that social organization is at once necessary and fatal. Men are forever creating such organizations for their own convenience and forever finding themselves the victims of their home-made monsters.

author: Andrew Cohen
title: One of the most extraordinary things about being a spiritual teacher is the rare privilege of being able to look deeply into the very souls of many human beings at the same time.

author: Dale Carnegie
title: One of the most tragic things I know about human nature is that all of us tend to put off living. We are all dreaming of some magical rose garden over the horizon - instead of enjoying the roses that are blooming outside our windows today.

author: Margaret Mead
title: One of the oldest human needs is having someone wonder where you are when you don't come home at night.

author: Malcolm Muggeridge
title: One of the peculiar sins of the twentieth century which we've developed to a very high level is the sin of credulity. It has been said that when human beings stop believing in God they believe in nothing. The truth is much worse: they believe in anything.

author: Virginia Woolf
title: One of the signs of passing youth is the birth of a sense of fellowship with other human beings as we take our place among them.

author: Alexander Pope
title: One science only will one genius fit; so vast is art, so narrow human wit.

author: Barbara Jordan
title: One thing is clear to me: We, as human beings, must be willing to accept people who are different from ourselves.

author: Edward M. Forster
title: Only connect! That was the whole of her sermon. Only connect the prose and the passion, and both will be exalted, and human love will be seen at its height. Live in fragments no longer. Only connect, and the beast and the monk, robbed of the isolation that is life to either, will die.

author: Elie Wiesel
title: Only one enemy is worse than despair: indifference. In every area of human creativity, indifference is the enemy; indifference of evil is worse than evil, because it is also sterile.

author: Laurence Sterne
title: Only the brave know how to forgive; it is the most refined and generous pitch of virtue human nature can arrive at.

author: Viktor E. Frankl
title: Only to the extent that someone is living out this self transcendence of human existence, is he truly human or does he become his true self. He becomes so, not by concerning himself with his self's actualization, but by forgetting himself and giving himself, overlooking himself and focusing outward.

author: Albert Einstein
title: Only two things are infinite, the universe and human stupidity, and I'm not sure about the former.

author: Emma Goldman
title: Only when human sorrows are turned into a toy with glaring colors will baby people become interested - for a while at least. The people are a very fickle baby that must have new toys every day.

author: John Erskine
title: Opinion is that exercise of the human will which helps us to make a decision without information.

author: Bertrand Russell
title: Order, unity, and continuity are human inventions, just as truly as catalogues and encyclopedias.

author: C. S. Lewis
title: Our cause is never more in danger than when a human, no longer desiring, but still intending to do our Enemy's will, looks round upon a universe from which every trace of Him seems to have vanished, and asks why he has been forsaken, and still obeys.

author: Jimmy Carter
title: Our commitment to human rights must be absolute, our laws fair, our natural beauty preserved; the powerful must not persecute the weak and human dignity must be enhanced.

author: Abraham J. Heschel
title: Our concern is not how to worship in the catacombs but how to remain human in the skyscrapers.

author: James A. Froude
title: Our human laws are more or less imperfect copies of the external laws as we see them.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Our ideals, like the gods of old, are constantly demanding human sacrifices.

author: Ban Ki-moon
title: Our planet's lands and oceans are already stretched to meet the demands of 7 billion people. The human population continues to grow. The search for sustainable solutions is an economic and a moral imperative if we are to create the future we want.

author: John F. Kennedy
title: Our problems are man-made, therefore they may be solved by man. No problem of human destiny is beyond human beings.

author: John F. Kennedy
title: Our progress as a nation can be no swifter than our progress in education. The human mind is our fundamental resource.

author: Ban Ki-moon
title: Our work for human dignity is often lonely, and almost always an uphill climb. At times, our efforts are misunderstood, and we are mistaken for the enemy. There has been a clear erosion of respect for U.N. blue and our impartiality.

author: Thomas E. Dewey
title: Ours is an abiding faith in the cause of human freedom. We know it is God's cause.

author: Brad Feld
title: Over the years, I've been involved in many business crises. I qualify this, since my crises have never involved life and death or the survival of the human race. But they are still crises.

author: George Tooker
title: Painting is an attempt to come to terms with life. There are as many solutions as there are human beings.

author: Cat Stevens
title: Peace Train is a song I wrote, the message of which continues to breeze thunderously through the hearts of millions of human beings.

author: Florence King
title: People are so busy dreaming the American Dream, fantasizing about what they could be or have a right to be, that they're all asleep at the switch. Consequently we are living in the Age of Human Error.

author: Blanka Vlasic
title: People don't come to stadiums only to see results. They come to see a reaction, they want to see we are also human, that we can cry or laugh.

author: Carl Lewis
title: People have always thought of me as being something, but I'm just a human being like everyone else.

author: Vaclav Havel
title: People who live in the post-totalitarian system know only too well that the question of whether one or several political parties are in power, and how these parties define and label themselves, is of far less importance than the question of whether or not it is possible to live like a human being.

author: James Baldwin
title: People who treat other people as less than human must not be surprised when the bread they have cast on the waters comes floating back to them, poisoned.

author: Amartya Sen
title: People's identities as Indians, as Asians, or as members of the human race, seemed to give way - quite suddenly - to sectarian identification with Hindu, Muslim, or Sikh communities.

author: Germaine Greer
title: Perhaps catastrophe is the natural human environment, and even though we spend a good deal of energy trying to get away from it, we are programmed for survival amid catastrophe.

author: Andre Norton
title: Perhaps it is because cats do not live by human patterns, do not fit themselves into prescribed behavior, that they are so united to creative people.

author: Bill Forsyth
title: Perhaps naively I thought people understand what humor was, that it was invented by the human race to cope with the dark areas of life, problems and terrors.

author: Kate Millet
title: Perhaps nothing is so depressing an index of the inhumanity of the male-supremacist mentality as the fact that the more genial human traits are assigned to the underclass: affection, response to sympathy, kindness, cheerfulness.

author: James Baldwin
title: Perhaps the whole root of our trouble, the human trouble, is that we will sacrifice all the beauty of our lives, will imprison ourselves in totems, taboos, crosses, blood sacrifices, steeples, mosques, races, armies, flags, nations, in order to deny the fact of death, which is the only fact we have.

author: James Baldwin
title: Pessimists are the people who have no hope for themselves or for others. Pessimists are also people who think the human race is beneath their notice, that they're better than other human beings.

author: Carl Sagan
title: Philosophers and scientists confidently offer up traits said to be uniquely human, and the monkeys and apes casually knock them down - toppling the pretension that humans constitute some sort of biological aristocracy among the beings on Earth.

author: William James
title: Philosophy is at once the most sublime and the most trivial of human pursuits.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Physically there is nothing to distinguish human society from the farm-yard except that children are more troublesome and costly than chickens and calves and that men and women are not so completely enslaved as farm stock.

author: Abba Eban
title: Playing the game I have learned the meaning of humility. It has given me an understanding of futility of the human effort.

author: Allen Ginsberg
title: Poetry is the one place where people can speak their original human mind. It is the outlet for people to say in public what is known in private.

author: Arthur Schopenhauer
title: Politeness is to human nature what warmth is to wax.

author: Vera Brittain
title: Politics are usually the executive expression of human immaturity.

author: Emma Goldman
title: Poor human nature, what horrible crimes have been committed in thy name!

author: Angela Carter
title: Pornographers are the enemies of women only because our contemporary ideology of pornography does not encompass the possibility of change, as if we were the slaves of history and not its makers. Pornography is a satire on human pretensions.

author: Camille Paglia
title: Pornography is human imagination in tense theatrical action; its violations are a protest against the violations of our freedom by nature.

author: Stephen Vizinczey
title: Powerful men in particular suffer from the delusion that human beings have no memories. I would go so far as to say that the distinguishing trait of powerful men is the psychotic certainty that people forget acts of infamy as easily as their parents birth

author: Ben Shapiro
title: Primarily affecting low-information voters and members of the mainstream media, Obama Worship Syndrome attributes impossible capabilities to Obama's political opponents, finds excuses for every Obama failure in everyone around him and praises the president as the finest politician - nay, human being - of our time.

author: Angela Davis
title: Prisons do not disappear social problems, they disappear human beings. Homelessness, unemployment, drug addiction, mental illness, and illiteracy are only a few of the problems that disappear from public view when the human beings contending with them are relegated to cages.

author: Martin Amis
title: Probably human cruelty is fixed and eternal. Only styles change.

author: Anthony de Mello
title: Problems only exist in the human mind.

author: Hannah Arendt
title: Promises are the uniquely human way of ordering the future, making it predictable and reliable to the extent that this is humanly possible.

author: Alphonse De Lamartine
title: Providence conceals itself in the details of human affairs, but becomes unveiled in the generalities of history.

author: Woodrow Wilson
title: Provision for others is a fundamental responsibility of human life.

author: Billy Graham
title: Racial prejudice, anti-Semitism, or hatred of anyone with different beliefs has no place in the human mind or heart.

author: Buzz Aldrin
title: Ray Bradbury is one who is contributing to the understanding of the imagination and the curiosity of the human race.

author: Sammy Davis Jr
title: Real success is not on the stage, but off the stage as a human being, and how you get along with your fellow man.

author: George Orwell
title: Reality exists in the human mind, and nowhere else.

author: Brenda Laurel
title: Reality has always been too small for the human imagination. We're always trying to transcend.

author: Virginia Woolf
title: Really I don't like human nature unless all candied over with art.

author: Aldo Leopold
title: Recreational development is a job not of building roads into the lovely country, but of building receptivity into the still unlovely human mind.

author: Carl Sagan
title: Relativity does set limits on what humans can ultimately do. But the universe is not required to be in perfect harmony with human aspirations.

author: Umberto Eco
title: Religion has nothing to do with God. It's a fundamental attitude of human beings, who ask about the origins of life and what happens after death. For many, the answer is a personal god. In my opinion, it's religion that produces God, not the other way round.

author: Susan Sontag
title: Religion is probably, after sex, the second oldest resource which human beings have available to them for blowing their minds.

author: Ludwig Feuerbach
title: Religion is the dream of the human mind. But even in dreams we do not find ourselves in emptiness or in heaven, but on earth, in the realm of reality; we only see real things in the entrancing splendor of imagination and caprice, instead of in the simple daylight of reality and necessity.

author: David M. Burns
title: Remember that fear always lurks behind perfectionism. Confronting your fears and allowing yourself the right to be human can, paradoxically, make you a far happier and more productive person.

author: Socrates
title: Remember, no human condition is ever permanent. Then you will not be overjoyed in good fortune nor too scornful in misfortune.

author: Buddy Ebsen
title: Remember, that of all the elements that comprise a human being, the most important, the most essential, the one that will sustain, transcend, overcome and vanquish obstacles is - Spirit!

author: Michael J. Gelb
title: Research shows that you begin learning in the womb and go right on learning until the moment you pass on. Your brain has a capacity for learning that is virtually limitless, which makes every human a potential genius.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Resolve not to be poor: whatever you have, spend less. Poverty is a great enemy to human happiness; it certainly destroys liberty, and it makes some virtues impracticable, and others extremely difficult.

author: Bill Bradley
title: Respect your fellow human being, treat them fairly, disagree with them honestly, enjoy their friendship, explore your thoughts about one another candidly, work together for a common goal and help one another achieve it.

author: Buzz Aldrin
title: Retain the vision for space exploration. If we turn our backs on the vision again, we're going to have to live in a secondary position in human space flight for the rest of the century.

author: Bobby Seale
title: Revolution is about the need to re-evolve political, economic and social justice and power back into the hands of the people, preferably through legislation and policies that make human sense. That's what revolution is about. Revolution is not about shootouts.

author: Abbie Hoffman
title: Revolution is not something fixed in ideology, nor is it something fashioned to a particular decade. It is a perpetual process embedded in the human spirit.

author: Blanche Lincoln
title: Right and wrong becomes more difficult for each of us as we grow older, because the older we get the more we know personally about our own human frailties.

author: Aleksander Kwasniewski
title: Righteous is the one who was able to demonstrate compassion in face of human suffering.

author: Virginia Woolf
title: Rigid, the skeleton of habit alone upholds the human frame.

author: Bill Bryson
title: Roads get wider and busier and less friendly to pedestrians. And all of the development based around cars, like big sprawling shopping malls. Everything seems to be designed for the benefit of the automobile and not the benefit of the human being.

author: Myriam Miedzian
title: Saving lives is not a top priority in the halls of power. Being compassionate and concerned about human life can cause a man to lose his job. It can cause a woman not to get the job to begin with.

author: John Keats
title: Scenery is fine, bui human nature is finer.

author: Jacob Bronowski
title: Science has nothing to be ashamed of even in the ruins of Nagasaki. The shame is theirs who appeal to other values than the human imaginative values which science has evolved.

author: Helen Keller
title: Science may have found a cure for most evils; but it has found no remedy for the worst of them all- the apathy of human beings.

author: Gordon Sumner
