title: Books serve to show a man that those original thoughts of his aren't very new at all.

author: Henry David Thoreau
title: Books, not which afford us a cowering enjoyment, but in which each thought is of unusual daring; such as an idle man cannot read, and a timid one would not be entertained by, which even make us dangerous to existing institution - such call I good books.

author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
title: Boyhood is a most complex and incomprehensible thing. Even when one has been through it, one does not understand what it was. A man can never quite understand a boy, even when he has been the boy.

author: Sir Walter Scott
title: Breathes there the man with soul so dead, Who never to himself hath said, This is my own, my native land!

author: Beilby Porteus
title: But chiefly Thou, Whom soft-eyed Pity once led down from Heaven To bleed for man, to teach him how to live, And, oh! still harder lesson! how to die.

author: Bruce Springsteen
title: But it's a sad man my friend who's livin' in his own skin , And can't stand the company. , Every fool's got a reason to feelin' sorry for himself , And turn his heart to stone. , Tonight this fool's halfway to heaven and just a mile outta hell , And I feel like I'm comin' home.

author: Ernest Hemingway
title: But man is not made for defeat. A man can be destroyed but not defeated.

author: George Eliot
title: But most of us are apt to settle within ourselves that the man who blocks our way is odious, and not to mind causing him a little of the disgust which his personality excites in ourselves.

author: Anne Hutchinson
title: But now having seen him which is invisible I fear not what man can do unto me.

author: Henry Louis Mencken
title: But that is a rare, rare man, I venture, who is as steadily intelligent, as constantly sound in judgment, as little put off by appearances, as the average women of forty-eight.

author: Oscar Wilde
title: But the bravest man amongst us is afraid of himself.

author: Elizabeth Barrett Browning
title: But the child's sob curses deeper in the silence than the strong man in his wrath!

author: George Eliot
title: But the mother's yearning, that completest type of the life in another life which is the essence of real human love, feels the presence of the cherished child even in the debased, degraded man.

author: Alan Paton
title: But the one thing that has power completely is love, because when a man loves, he seeks no power, and therefore he has power.

author: Thomas Hood
title: But who would rush at a benighted man, and give him two black eyes for being blind?

author: Immanuel Kant
title: By a lie, a man...annihilates his dignity as a man.

author: John Kenneth Galbraith
title: By all but the pathologically romantic, it is now recognized that this is not the age of the small man.

author: Claude Adrien Helvétius
title: By annihilating the desires, you annihilate the mind. Every man without passions has within him no principle of action, nor motive to act.

author: Democritus
title: By desiring little, a poor man makes himself rich.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: By nature man hates change; seldom will he quit his old home till it has actually fallen around his ears.

author: Oscar Wilde
title: By persistently remaining single, a man converts himself into a permanent public temptation. Men should be more careful.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: By taking a second wife he pays the highest compliment to the first, by showing that she made him so happy as a married man, that he wishes to be so a second time.

author: Robert S. Hillyer
title: By the age of twenty, any young man should know whether or not he is to be a specialist and just where his tastes lie. By postponing the question we have set on immaturity a premium which controls most American personality to its deathbed.

author: Dwight L. Moody
title: By the grace of God, I'll be that man.

author: Jackie Mason
title: By these things examine thyself. By whose rules am I acting; in whose name; in whose strength; in whose glory? What faith, humility, self-denial, and love of God and to man have there been in all my actions?

author: Thomas à Kempis
title: By two wings a man is lifted up from things earthly: by simplicity and purity.

author: Solomon Schechter
title: By vulgarity I mean that vice of civilization which makes man ashamed of himself and his next of kin, and pretend to be somebody else.

author: E. F. Schumacher
title: Call a thing immoral or ugly, soul-destroying or a degradation of man, a peril to the peace of the world or to the well-being of future generations; as long as you have not shown it to be ''uneconomic'' you have not really questioned its right to exist, grow, and prosper.

author: Aeschylus
title: Call no man happy till he is dead.

author: Socrates
title: Call no man unhappy until he is married.

author: Helen Rowland
title: Call the bald man, ''Boy;'' make the sage thy toy; greet the youth with solemn face; praise the fat man for his grace.

author: Walt Whitman
title: Camerado! This is no book; who touches this touches a man.

author: Blaise Pascal
title: Can anything be stupider than that a man has the right to kill me because he lives on the other side of a river and his ruler has a quarrel with mine, though I have not quarrelled with him?

author: Sidonie Gabrielle Colette
title: Can it be that chance has made me one of those women so immersed in one man that, whether they are barren or not, they carry with them to the grave the shriveled innocence of an old maid?

author: John Gay
title: Can you support the expense of a husband, hussy, in gaming, drinking and whoring? Have you money enough to carry on the daily quarrels of man and wife about who shall squander most?

author: William Cowper
title: Candid and generous and just. Boys care but little whom they trust. An error soon corrected - for who but learns in riper years. That man, when smoothest he appears, is most to be suspected?

author: James Fenimore Cooper
title: Candor is a proof of both a just frame of mind, and of a good tone of breeding. It is a quality that belongs equally to the honest man and to the gentleman.

author: Vladimir Ilyich Lenin
title: Capitalists are no more capable of self-sacrifice than a man is capable of lifting himself up by his own bootstraps.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: Cash-payment is not the sole nexus of man with man.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: Cash-payment never was, or could except for a few years be, the union-bond of man to man. Cash never yet paid one man fully his deserts to another; nor could it, nor can it, now or henceforth to the end of the world.

author: B. R. Ambedkar
title: Caste may be bad. Caste may lead to conduct so gross as to be called man's inhumanity to man. All the same, it must be recognized that the Hindus observe Caste not because they are inhuman or wrong-headed. They observe Caste because they are deeply religious.

author: Karl Marx
title: Catch a man a fish, and you can sell it to him. Teach a man to fish, and you ruin a wonderful business opportunity.

author: Carl Jung
title: Caution has its place, no doubt, but we cannot refuse our support to a serious venture which challenges the whole of the personality. If we oppose it, we are trying to suppress what is best in man -his daring and his aspirations. And should we succeed, we should only have stood in the way of that invaluable experience which might have given a meaning to life. What would have happened if Paul had allowed himself to be talked out of his journey to Damascus?

author: Jonathan Swift
title: Censure is the tax a man pays to the public for being eminent.

author: Aristotle
title: Character is that which reveals moral purpose, exposing the class of things a man chooses or avoids.

author: Napoleon Hill
title: Character is to man what carbon is to steel.

author: Dwight L. Moody
title: Character is what a man is in the dark.

author: Booker T. Washington
title: Character, not circumstances, makes the man.,

author: Camille Paglia
title: Charisma is the radiance produced by the interaction of male and female elements in a gifted personality. The charismatic woman has a masculine force and severity. The charismatic man has an entrancing female beauty. Both are hot and cold, glowing with presexual self-love.

author: Thomas Browne
title: Charity But how shall we expect charity towards others, when we are uncharitable to ourselves? Charity begins at home, is the voice of the world; yet is every man his greatest enemy, and, as it were, his own executioner.

author: Thomas B. Macaulay
title: Charles V. said that a man who knew four languages was worth four men; and Alexander the Great so valued learning, that he used to say he was more indebted to Aristotle for giving him knowledge that, than his father Philip for giving him life.

author: John Milton
title: Childhood shows the man, as morning shows the day.

author: Anna Jameson
title: Childhood sometimes does pay a second visit to man; youth never.

author: Albert Camus
title: Children will still die unjustly even in a perfect society. Even by his greatest effort, man can only propose to diminish, arithmetically, the sufferings of the world.

author: Abbott Eliot Kittredge
title: Christianity claims that the supernatural is as reasonable as the natural, that man himself is supernatural as truly as he is natural, and that the Bible is so clearly the word of God by proofs that are unanswerable, that it is unreasonable to disbelieve its divine truths.

author: Dwight L. Moody
title: Church attendance is as vital to a disciple as a transfusion of rich, healthy blood to a sick man.

author: Oscar Wilde
title: Civilization is not by any means an easy thing to attain to. There are only two ways by which man can reach it. One is by being cultured, the other by being corrupt.

author: Ayn Rand
title: Civilization is the progress toward a society of privacy. The savage's whole existence is public, ruled by the laws of his tribe. Civilization is the process of setting man free from men.

author: Cyril Connolly
title: Classical and romantic: private language of a family quarrel, a dead dispute over the distribution of emphasis between man and nature.

author: Thomas Otway
title: Clocks will go as they are set, but man, irregular man, is never constant, never certain.

author: Victor Hugo
title: Close by the Rights of Man, at the least set beside them, are the Rights of the Spirit.

author: Henry Ward Beecher
title: Clothes and manners do not make the man; but when he is made, they greatly improve his appearance

author: Mark Twain
title: Clothes make the man. Naked people have little or no influence on society.

author: Babe Ruth
title: Cobb is a prick. But he sure can hit. God Almighty, that man can hit.

author: John Sterling
title: Colors answer feeling in man; shapes answer thought; and motion answers will.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Commerce is of trivial import; love, faith, truth of character, the aspiration of man, these are sacred.

author: Elwyn Brooks White
title: Commuter - one who spends his life in riding to and from his wife; And man who shaves and takes a train, and then rides back to shave again.

author: Andrew Carnegie
title: Concentrate your energies, your thoughts and your capital. The wise man puts all his eggs in one basket and watches the basket.

author: Albert Einstein
title: Concern for man and his fate must always form the chief interest of all technical endeavors. Never forget this in the midst of your diagrams and equations.

author: Pythagoras
title: Concern should drive us into action and not into a depression. No man is free who cannot control himself.

author: Malcolm X
title: Concerning non-violence: it is criminal to teach a man not to defend himself when he is the constant victim of brutal attacks.

author: James Freeman Clarke
title: Conscience is the root of all true courage; if a man would be brave let him obey his conscience.

author: John Fowles
title: Content is a word unknown to life; it is also a word unknown to man.

author: James Whitcomb Riley
title: Continuous, unflagging effort, persistence and determination will win. Let not the man be discouraged who has these.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Conversation is an art in which a man has all mankind for competitors.

author: William Shakespeare
title: Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy, but not expressed in fancy; rich not gaudy; for the apparel oft proclaims the man.

author: A. E. Housman
title:
Could man be drunk for ever ,
 With liquor, love, or fights, ,
 Lief should I rouse at mornings ,
 And lief lie down of nights. ,
 But men at whiles are sober ,
 And think by fits and starts, ,
 And if they think, they fasten ,
 Their hands upon their hearts.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Courage charms us, because it indicates that a man loves an idea better than all things in the world, that he is thinking neither of his bed, nor his dinner, nor his money, but will venture all to put in act the invisible thought of his mind.

author: Billy Graham
title: Courage is contagious. When a brave man takes a stand, the spines of others are often stiffened.

author: Jean Genet
title: Crimes of which a people is ashamed constitute its real history. The same is true of man.

author: Jean de la Bruyère
title: Criticism is often not a science; it is a craft, requiring more good health than wit, more hard work than talent, more habit than native genius. In the hands of a man who has read widely but lacks judgment, applied to certain subjects it can corrupt both its readers and the writer himself.

author: Caleb Cushing
title: Cruel war, war at home; and in the perspective distance, a man on horseback with a drawn sword in his hand, some Atlantic Caesar, or Cromwell, or Napoleon.

author: Oscar Wilde
title: Cultivated leisure is the aim of man.

author: Paul De Man
title: Curiously enough, it seems to be only in describing a mode of language which does not mean what it says that one can actually say what one means.

author: Abu Bakr
title: Cursed is the man who dies, but the evil done by him survives.

author: Lord Chesterfield
title: Custom has made dancing sometimes necessary for a young man; therefore mind it while you learn it, that you may learn to do it well, and not be ridiculous, though in a ridiculous act.

author: Andre Breton
title: Dali is like a man who hesitates between talent and genius, or, as one might once have said, between vice and virtue.

author: Christopher Morley
title: Dancing is a wonderful training for girls, it's the first way you learn to guess what a man is going to do before he does it.

author: W. S. Gilbert
title: Darwinian man, though well-behaved, at best is only a monkey shaved.

author: Edward M. Forster
title: Death destroys a man, the idea of Death saves him.

author: Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe
title: Death is a commingling of eternity with time; in the death of a good man, eternity is seen looking through time.

author: Paul De Man
title: Death is a displaced name for a linguistic predicament.

author: Nelson Mandela
title: Death is something inevitable. When a man has done what he considers to be his duty to his people and his country, he can rest in peace. I believe I have made that effort and that is, therefore, why I will sleep for the eternity.

author: Jean de la Fontaine
title: Death never takes the wise man by surprise, he is always ready to go.

author: Adam Clarke
title: Death to a good man is but passing through a dark entry, out of one little dusky room of his Father's house into another that is fair and large, lightsome and glorious, and divinely entertaining.

author: Elwyn Brooks White
title: Deathlessness should be arrived at in a... haphazard fashion. Loving fame as much as any man, we shall carve our initials in the shell of a tortoise and turn him loose in a peat bog.

author: Richard Nixon
title: Defeat doesn't finish a man - quit does. A man is not finished when he's defeated. He's finished when he quits.

author: Aldous Huxley
title: Defined in psychological terms, a fanatic is a man who consciously over-compensates a secret doubt.

author: William Hazlitt
title: Defoe says that there were a hundred thousand country fellows in his time ready to fight to the death against popery, without knowing whether popery was a man or a horse.

author: James Russell Lowell
title: Democracy give every man the right to be his own oppressor.

author: Laurence J. Peter
title: Democracy is a process by which the people are free to choose the man who will get the blame.

author: Bertrand Russell
title: Democracy is the process by which people choose the man who'll get the blame.

author: Johann Kaspar Lavater
title: Depend on no man, on no friend but him who can depend on himself. He only who acts conscientiously toward himself, will act so toward others.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Depend upon it that if a man talks of his misfortunes there is something in them that is not disagreeable to him.

author: Baruch Spinoza
title: Desire is the essence of a man.

author: Carl Stokes
title: Despite the litany of the sorrows of the city, we must believe in the ability of man to respond to the problems of his environment.

author: Aeschylus
title: Destiny waits alike for the free man as well as for him enslaved by another's might.

author: Bruce Greenwood
title: Did I get jiggy with Will? I would have to say no! Did I have fun with Will? I would have to say yeah! But you know, I did not jig with the man, if you know what I'm saying!

author: Miguel de Cervantes
title: Diligence is the mother of good fortune, and idleness, its opposite, never brought a man to the goal of any of his best wishes.

author: Oscar Wilde
title: Discontent is the first step in the progress of a man or a nation.

author: Abraham Lincoln
title: Discourage litigation. Persuade your neighbors to compromise whenever you can. As a peacemaker the lawyer has superior opportunity of being a good man. There will still be business enough.

author: Jacob Bronowski
title: Dissent is the native activity of the scientist, and it has got him into a good deal of trouble in the last years. But if that is cut off, what is left will not be a scientist. And I doubt whether it will be a man.

author: Henry David Thoreau
title:
Do not hire a man who does your work for money, but him who does it for love of it.,
,
,
,
,

author: Ernest Hemingway
title: Do not judge a man by his friends; do not forget that Judas friends were impeccable.

author: Thomas à Kempis
title: Do not let your peace depend on the hearts of men; whatever they say about you, good or bad, you are not because of it another man, for as you are, you are.

author: Allan Massie
title: Do you know what a soldier is, young man? He's the chap who makes it possible for civilized folk to despise war.

author: Augustus William Hare
title: Do you wish to find out a person's weak points? Note the failings he has the quickest eye for in others. They may not be the very failings he is himself conscious of; but they will be their next-door neighbors. No man keeps such a jealous lookout as a rival.

author: Arnold Bennett
title: Does there, I wonder, exist a being who has read all, or approximately all, that the person of average culture is supposed to have read, and that not to have read is a social sin? If such a being does exist, surely he is an old, a very old man.

author: Charles Lamb
title: Don't introduce me to that man! I want to go on hating him, and I can't hate a man whom I know.

author: Finley Peter Dunne
title: Don't jump on a man unless he is down.

author: Robert C. Edwards
title: Don't place too much confidence in the man who boasts of being as honest as the day is long. Wait until you meet him at night.

author: Wernher Von Braun
title: Don't tell me that man doesn't belong out there. Man belongs wherever he wants to go - and he'll do plenty well when he gets there.

author: St. Augustine of Hippo
title: Don't you believe that there is in man a deep so profound as to be hidden even to him in whom it is?

author: William Shakespeare
title: Doth not the appetite alter? A man loves the meat in his youth that he cannot endure in his age.

author: Francis Herbert Hedge
title: Dreaming is an act of pure imagination, attesting in all men a creative power, which, if it were available in waking, would make every man a Dante or Shakespeare.

author: Augustus Baldwin Longstreet
title: During the session of the Supreme Court, in the village of -, about three weeks ago, when a number of people were collected in the principal street of the village, I observed a young man riding up and down the street, as I supposed, in a violent passion.

author: Mark Twain
title: Duties are not performed for duty's sake, but because their neglect would make the man uncomfortable. A man performs but one duty -the duty of contenting his spirit, the duty of making himself agreeable to himself.

author: Joseph Conrad
title: Each blade of grass has its spot on earth whence it draws its life, its strength; and so is man rooted to the land from which he draws his faith together with his life.

author: Marie Carmichael Stopes
title: Each coming together of man and wife, even if they have been mated for many years, should be a fresh adventure; each winning should necessitate a fresh wooing.

author: Charles Kingsley
title: Each man can learn something from his neighbour, at least he can learn this, to have patience with his neighbour, to live and let live.

author: Virgil
title: Each man has his appointed day: short and irreparable in the brief life of all, but to extend our fame by our deeds, this is the work of mankind.

author: Aulus Persius Flaccus
title: Each man has his own desires; all do not possess the same inclinations.

author: John Oxenham
title:
Each man is Captain of his Soul,,
And each man his own Crew,

author: J. Oxenham
title: Each man is captain of his soul.

author: Remy de Gourmont
title: Each man must grant himself the emotions that he needs and the morality that suits him.

author: Charles Horton Cooley
title: Each man must have his ''I''; it is more necessary to him than bread; and if he does not find scope for it within the existing institutions he will be likely to make trouble.

author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
title: Each man must look to himself to teach him the meaning of life. It is not something discovered: it is something molded.

author: Victor Hugo
title: Each man should frame life so that at some future hour fact and his dreaming meet.

author: Tim O'Brien
title: Each of us, I suppose needs his illusions. Life after death. A maker of planets. A woman to love, a man to hate. Something sacred. But what a waste.

author: Camille Paglia
title: Earisome as it may seem, women must realize that, in making a commitment to a man, they have merged in his unconscious with his mother and have therefore inherited the ambivalence of that relationship.

author: Benjamin Franklin
title: Early to bed and early to rise, makes a man healthy, wealthy, and wise.

author: Barbara Tuchman
title: Economic man and sensual man are not suppressible.

author: Ambrose Bierce
title: Edible. Good to eat and wholesome to digest, as a worm to a toad, a toad to a snake, a snake to a pig, a pig to a man, and a man to a worm.

author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel
title: Education is the art of making man ethical.

author: Henry Ward Beecher
title: Education is the knowledge of how to use the whole of oneself. Many men use but one or two faculties out of the score with which they are endowed. A man is educated who knows how to make a tool of every faculty - how to open it, how to keep it sharp, and how to apply it to all practical purposes.

author: C. S. Lewis
title: Education without values, as useful as it is, seems rather to make man a more clever devil.

author: Conrad Hilton
title: Enthusiasm is a vital element toward the individual success of every man or woman.

author: Christian Nevell Bovee
title: Enthusiasm is the inspiration of everything great. Without it no man is to be feared, and with it none despised.

author: Ovid
title: Envy feeds on the living, after death it rests, then the honor of a man protects him.

author: Albert Schweitzer
title: Ethics is the activity of man directed to secure the inner perfection of his own personality.

author: Bono
title: Ethiopia didn't just blow my mind; it opened my mind. Anyway, on our last day at this orphanage a man handed me his baby and said, 'Would you take my son with you?' He knew, in Ireland, that his son would live, and that in Ethiopia, his son would die.

author: Aldous Huxley
title: Europe is so well gardened that it resembles a work of art, a scientific theory, a neat metaphysical system. Man has re-created Europe in his own image.

author: C. S. Lewis
title: Even in literature and art, no man who bothers about originality will ever be original: whereas if you simply try to tell the truth (without caring twopence how often it has been told before) you will, nine times out of ten, become original without ever having noticed it.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: Even in the meanest sorts of labor, the whole soul of a man is composed into a kind of real harmony the instant he sets himself to work.

author: John Berger
title: Every city has a sex and an age which have nothing to do with demography. Rome is feminine. So is Odessa. London is a teenager, an urchin, and, in this, hasn't changed since the time of Dickens. Paris, I believe, is a man in his twenties in love with an older woman.

author: Robert Collier
title: Every contrivance of man, every tool, every instrument, every utensil, every article designed for use, of each and every kind, evolved from a very simple beginnings.

author: Oliver Wendell Holmes
title: Every event that a man would master must be mounted on the run, and no man ever caught the reins of a thought except as it galloped past him.

author: Harry Anderson
title: Every fool knows you can't touch the stars, but it doesn't stop a wise man from trying.

author: John Ruskin
title: Every great man is always being helped by everybody; for his gift is to get good out of all things and all persons.

author: Charles Baudelaire
title: Every idea is endowed of itself with immortal life, like a human being. All created form, even that which is created by man, is immortal. For form is independent of matter: molecules do not constitute form.

author: Janet Malcolm
title: Every journalist who is not too stupid or too full of himself to notice what is going on knows that what he does is morally indefensible. He is a kind of confidence man, preying on people's vanity, ignorance, or loneliness, gaining their trust and betraying them without remorse.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Every man alone is sincere. At the entrance of a second person, hypocrisy begins.

author: Benjamin E. Mays
title: Every man and woman is born into the world to do something unique and something distinctive and if he or she does not do it, it will never be done.

author: Lord Chesterfield
title: Every man becomes, to a certain degree, what the people he generally converses with are.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Every man believes that he has greater possibilities.

author: Ayn Rand
title: Every man builds his world in his own image. He has the power to choose, but no power to escape the necessity of choice.

author: Marcus Tullius Cicero
title: Every man can tell how many goats or sheep he possesses, but not how many friends.

author: Jonathan Swift
title: Every man desires to live long, but no man would be old.

author: James Russell Lowell
title: Every man feels instinctively that all the beautiful sentiments in the world weigh less than a single lovely action.

author: Robert Burton
title: Every man for himself, his own ends, the Devil for all.

author: Robert Burton
title: Every man for himself, the devil for all.

author: Konrad Lorenz
title: Every man gets a narrower and narrower field of knowledge in which he must be an expert in order to compete with other people. The specialist knows more and more about less and less and finally knows everything about nothing.

author: Bob Marley
title:
Every man gotta right to decide his own destiny.,
,

author: Camille Paglia
title: Every man harbors an inner female territory ruled by his mother, from whom he can never entirely break free.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Every man has a lurking wish to appear considerable in his native place.

author: John Locke
title: Every man has a property in his own person. This nobody has a right to, but himself.

author: Jean Paul
title: Every man has a rainy corner of his life whence comes foul weather which follows him.

author: Benjamin Disraeli
title: Every man has a right to be conceited until he is successful.

author: Bernard M. Baruch
title: Every man has a right to be wrong in his opinions. But no man has a right to be wrong in his facts.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Every man has a right to utter what he thinks truth, and every other man has a right to knock him down for it. Martyrdom is the test.

author: Robert Louis Stevenson
title: Every man has a sane spot somewhere.

author: Barbara Cartland
title: Every man has been brought up with the idea that decent women don't pop in and out of bed; he has always been told by his mother that nice girls don't. He finds, of course, when he gets older that this may be untrue - but only in a certain section of society.

author: Denis Diderot
title: Every man has his dignity. I'm willing to forget mine, but at my own discretion and not when someone else tells me to.

author: Josh Billings
title: Every man has his follies - and often they are the most interesting thing he had got.

author: G. C. Lichtenberg
title: Every man has his moral backside which he refrains from showing unless he has to and keeps covered as long as possible with the trousers of decorum.

author: Henry Miller
title: Every man has his own destiny: the only imperative is to follow it, to accept it, no matter where it leads him.

author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau
title: Every man has the right to risk his own life in order to save it.

author: Alphonse Karr
title: Every man has three characters - that which he exhibits, that which he has, and that which he thinks he has.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Every man has, some time in his life, an ambition to be a wag.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Every man I meet is in some way my superior.

author: William Saroyan
title: Every man in the world is better than someone else and not as good someone else.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Every man is a consumer and ought to be a producer.

author: Sir Herbert Beerbohm Tree
title: Every man is a potential genius until he does something.

author: Norman Douglas
title: Every man is a solitary in his grief.

author: William Ellery Channing
title: Every man is a volume if you know how to read him.

author: Oliver Wendell Holmes
title: Every man is an omnibus in which his ancestors ride.

author: Miguel de Cervantes
title: Every man is as heaven made him, and sometimes a great deal worse.

author: Martin Heidegger
title: Every man is born as many men and dies as a single one.

author: Robert Green Ingersoll
title: Every man is dishonest who lives upon the labor of others, no matter if he occupies a throne.

author: Francis Herbert Hedge
title: Every man is his own ancestor, and every man his own heir. He devises his own fortune, and he inherits his own past.

author: Anacharsis
title: Every man is his own chief enemy.

author: Euripides
title: Every man is like the company he is wont to keep.

author: Aleksander Kwasniewski
title: Every man is responsible only for his own acts. The sons do not inherit the sins of the fathers. But can we say: that was long ago, they were different?

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Every man is rich or poor according to the proportion between his desires and his enjoyments.

author: Abraham Lincoln
title: Every man is said to have his peculiar ambition. Whether it be true or not, I can say for one that I have no other so great as that of being truly esteemed of my fellow men, by rendering myself worthy of their esteem.

author: Jane Austen
title: Every man is surrounded by a neighborhood of voluntary spies.

author: Paul Auster
title: Every man is the author of his own life.

author: Henry David Thoreau
title: Every man is the builder of a temple, called his body, to the god he worships, after a style purely his own, nor can he get off by hammering marble instead. We are all sculptors and painters, and our material is our own flesh and blood and bones.

author: Voltaire
title: Every man is the creature of the age in which he lives; very few are able to raise themselves above the ideas of the time.

author: Sir Richard Steele
title: Every man is the maker of his own fortune.

author: Miguel de Cervantes
title: Every man is the son of his own works.

author: T. Shadwell
title: Every man loves what he is good at.

author: Camille Paglia
title: Every man must define his identity against his mother. If he does not, he just falls back into her and is swallowed up.

author: Martin Luther
title: Every man must do two things alone; he must do his own believing and his own dying.

author: Frederick the Great
title: Every man must get to Heaven his own way.

author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow
title: Every man must patiently bide his time. He must wait - not in listless idleness but in constant, steady, cheerful endeavors, always willing and fulfilling and accomplishing his task, that when the occasion comes he may be equal to the occasion.

author: Iris Murdoch
title: Every man needs two women, a quiet home-maker, and a thrilling nymph.

author: Sextus Propertius
title: Every man now worships gold, all other reverence being done away.

author: Charles de Gaulle
title: Every man of action has a strong dose of egoism, pride, hardness, and cunning. But all those things will be regarded as high qualities if he can make them the means to achieve great ends.

author: Oscar Wilde
title: Every man of ambition has to fight his century with its own weapons. What this century worships is wealth. The God of this century is wealth. To succeed one must have wealth. At all costs one must have wealth.

author: Abraham Lincoln
title: Every man over forty is responsible for his face.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Every man passes his life in the search after friendship.

author: Henry Louis Mencken
title: Every man sees in his relatives, and especially in his cousins, a series of grotesque caricatures of himself.

author: Henry Ward Beecher
title: Every man should keep a fair-sized cemetery in which to bury the faults of his friends.

author: Arthur Schopenhauer
title: Every man takes the limits of his own field of vision for the limits of the world.

author: Jean Anouilh
title: Every man thinks God is on his side. The rich and powerful know He is.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Every man thinks meanly of himself for not having been a soldier, or not having been at sea.

author: Helen Rowland
title: Every man wants a woman to appeal to his better side, his nobler instincts and his higher nature - and another woman to help him forget them.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Every man who attacks my belief, diminishes in some degree my confidence in it, and therefore makes me uneasy; and I am angry with him who makes me uneasy.

author: Sir James Matthew Barrie
title: Every man who is high up loves to think that he has done it all himself; and the wife smiles, and lets it go at that.

author: Aldous Huxley
title: Every man who knows how to read has it in his power to magnify himself, to multiply the ways in which he exists, to make his life full, significant and interesting.

author: Edward Bulwer-Lytton
title: Every man who observes vigilantly and resolves steadfastly grows unconsciously into genius.

author: William James
title: Every man who possibly can should force himself to a holiday of a full month in a year, whether he feels like taking it or not.

author: B. R. Ambedkar
title: Every man who repeats the dogma of Mill that one country is no fit to rule another country must admit that one class is not fit to rule another class.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Every man who would do anything well, must come to it from a higher ground.

author: Cardinal de Retz
title: Every man whom chance alone has, by some accident, made a public character, hardly ever fails of becoming, in a short time, a ridiculous private one.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Every man wishes to be wise, and they who cannot be wise are almost always cunning.

author: Henry Miller
title: Every man with a bellyful of the classics is an enemy to the human race.

author: Claude Adrien Helvétius
title: Every man without passion has within him no principle of action, nor motive of act.

author: Ernest Hemingway
title: Every man's life ends the same way. It is only the details of how he lived and how he died that distinguish one man from another.

author: Plautus
title: Every man, however wise, needs the advice of some sagacious friend in the affairs of life.

author: William Hazlitt
title: Every man, in his own opinion, forms an exception to the ordinary rules of morality.

author: Alfred Lord Tennyson
title: Every moment dies a man, every moment one is born.

author: Henry Louis Mencken
title: Every normal man must be tempted at times to spit upon his hands, hoist the black flag, and begin slitting throats.

author: Thomas Paine
title: Every religion is good that teaches man to be good; and I know of none that instructs him to be bad.

author: Edgar W. Howe
title: Every successful man I have heard of has done the best he could with conditions as he found them...

author: Germaine Greer
title: Every time a man unburdens his heart to a stranger he reaffirms the love that unites humanity.

author: Germaine Greer
title: Every time a woman makes herself laugh at her husband's often-told jokes she betrays him. The man who looks at his woman and says ''What would I do without you?'' is already destroyed.

author: Luigi Pirandello
title: Every true man, sir, who is a little above the level of the beasts and plants does not live for the sake of living, without knowing how to live; but he lives so as to give a meaning and a value of his own to life.

author: Joseph Brodsky
title: Every writing career starts as a personal quest for sainthood, for self-betterment. Sooner or later, and as a rule quite soon, a man discovers that his pen accomplishes a lot more than his soul.

author: Desiderius Erasmus
title: Everyone knows that by far the happiest and universally enjoyable age of man is the first. What is there about babies which makes us hug and kiss and fondle them, so that even an enemy would give them help at that age?

author: Viktor E. Frankl
title: Everything can be taken away from a man but one thing: the last of the human freedom - to choose one's attitude in any given set of circumstances, to choose one's own way.

author: Benjamin Disraeli
title: Everything comes if a man will only wait.

author: Eric Butterworth
title: Evil, and evil spirits, devils and devil possession, are the outgrowth of man's inadequate consciousness of God. We must avoid thinking of evil as a thing in itself-a force that works against man or, against God, if you will.

author: Charles Caleb Colton
title: Examinations are formidable even to the best prepared, for the greatest fool may ask more than the wisest man can answer.

author: Oscar Wilde
title: Examinations, sir, are pure humbug from beginning to end. If a man is a gentleman, he knows quite enough, and if he is not a gentleman, whatever he knows is bad for him.

author: Jose Ortega Y Gasset
title: Excellence means when a man or woman asks of himself more than others do.

author: Aristotle
title: Excellence, then, is a state concerned with choice, lying in a mean, relative to us, this being determined by reason and in the way in which the man of practical wisdom would determine it.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Except during the nine months before he draws his first breath, no man manages his affairs as well as a tree does.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Except during the nine months before he draws his first breath, no man manages his affairs as well as a tree. We are inclined to believe those whom we do not know because they have never deceived us.

author: Alfred H. Barr
title: Except the American woman, nothing interests the eye of American man more than the automobile, or seems so important to him as an object of aesthetic appreciation.

author: Thomas Jefferson
title: Experience demands that man is the only animal which devours his own kind, for I can apply no milder term to the general prey of the rich on the poor.

author: Josh Billings
title: Experience is a school where a man learns what a big fool he has been.

author: Aldous Huxley
title: Experience is not what happens to a man; it is what a man does with what happens to him.

author: Alexander Pope
title: Extremes in nature equal ends produce; In man they join to some mysterious use.

author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
title: Fable is more historical than fact, because fact tells us about one man and fable tells us about a million men.

author: Charles de Gaulle
title: Faced with crisis, the man of character falls back on himself. He imposes his own stamp of action, takes responsibility for it, makes it his own.

author: Helen Rowland
title: Failing to be there when a man wants her is a woman's greatest sin, except to be there when he doesn't want her.

author: Elbert Hubbard
title: Failure - The man who can tell others what to do and how to do it, but never does it himself.

author: Martin Luther
title: Faith is a living, daring confidence in God's grace, so sure and certain that a man could stake his life on it a thousand times.

author: Abraham J. Heschel
title: Faith is an awareness of divine mutuality and companionship, a form of communion between God and man. It is not a psychical quality, something that exists in the mind only, but a force from the beyond.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: Fame, we may understand, is no sure test of merit, but only a probability of such; it is an accident, not a property of man.

author: Paul De Man
title: Fashion is like the ashes left behind by the uniquely shaped flames of the fire, the trace alone revealing that a fire actually took place.

author: Marian Anderson
title: Fear is a disease that eats away at logic and makes man inhuman.

author: Sir Philip Sidney
title: Fearfulness, contrary to all other vices, maketh a man think the better of another, the worse of himself.

author: Mignon McLaughlin
title: Few women care what a man looks like, and a good thing too.

author: Abraham Cowley
title:
Fill all the glasses there, for why ,
 Should every creature drink but I? ,
 Why, man of morals, tell me why?

author: Helen Rowland
title: Flirting is the gentle art of making a man feel pleased with himself.

author: Caitlin Moran
title: Flyaway, problem hair is the enemy of feminism, and was probably invented by the Man to crush Susan Sontag.

author: Albert Ellis
title: For a man there are three certainties in life: death, taxes, and women. It is often difficult to say which is the worst.

author: Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe
title: For a man to achieve all that is demanded of him he must regard himself as greater than he is.

author: Miguel de Cervantes
title: For a man to attain to an eminent degree in learning costs him time, watching, hunger, nakedness, dizziness in the head, weakness in the stomach, and other inconveniences.

author: Queen Victoria
title: For a man to strike any women is most brutal, and I, as well as everyone else, think this far worse than any attempt to shoot, which, wicked as it is, is at least more comprehensible and more courageous.

author: Ludwig Wittgenstein
title: For a truly religious man nothing is tragic.

author: Carl Jung
title: For a woman, the typical danger emanating from the unconscious comes from above, from the spiritual sphere personified by the animus, whereas for a man it comes from the chthonic realm of the world and woman, i.e., the anima projected on to the world.

author: Hal Borland
title: For all his learning or sophistication, man still instinctively reaches towards that force beyond. Only arrogance can deny its existence, and the denial falters in the face of evidence on every hand. In every tuft of grass, in every bird, in every opening bud, there it is.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: For all right judgment of any man or things it is useful, nay, essential, to see his good qualities before pronouncing on his bad.

author: Blaise Pascal
title: For as old age is that period of life most remote from infancy, who does not see that old age in this universal man ought not to be sought in the times nearest his birth, but in those most remote from it?

author: Albert Camus
title: For centuries the death penalty, often accompanied by barbarous refinements, has been trying to hold crime in check; yet crime persists. Why? Because the instincts that are warring in man are not, as the law claims, constant forces in a state of equilibrium.

author: Aeschylus
title: For children preserve the fame of a man after his death.

author: Robert Louis Stevenson
title: For God's sake give me the young man who has brains enough to make a fool of himself!

author: Joyce Cary
title: For good and evil, man is a free creative spirit. This produces the very queer world we live in, a world in continuous creation and therefore continuous change and insecurity.

author: William Somerset Maugham
title: For if the proper study of mankind is man, it is evidently more sensible to occupy yourself with the coherent, substantial and significant creatures of fiction than with the irrational and shadowy figures of real life.

author: Boethius
title: For in every ill-turn of fortune the most unhappy sort of unfortunate man is the one who has been happy.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: For man is not the creature and product of Mechanism; but, in a far truer sense, its creator and producer.

author: Ernest Becker
title: For man, maximum excitement is the confrontation of death and the skillful defiance of it by watching others fed to it as he survives transfixed with rapture.

author: Brendan Gleeson
title: For me, it's just about keeping the standards up. We're a small country, so we have to punch above our weight. I'm not a great man for doing something just because it's Irish, and you never know what's going to work. But as long as we keep the standards up, people will continue to invest in films. It's as simple as that.

author: Lord Chesterfield
title: For my own part, I would rather be in company with a dead man than with an absent one; for if the dead man gives me no pleasure, at least he shows me no contempt; whereas the absent one, silently indeed, but very plainly, tells me that he does not think me worth his attention.

author: John Milton
title: For neither man nor angel can discern hypocrisy, the only evil that walks invisible, except to God alone.

author: Christina Rossetti
title: For one man is my world of all the men this wide world holds; O love, my world is you.

author: Haniel Long
title: For support, I fall back on my heart. Has a man any fault a woman cannot weave with and try to change into something better, if the god her man prays to is a mother holding a baby?

author: George Robert Gissing
title: For the man sound of body and serene of mind there is no such thing as bad weather; every day has its beauty, and storms which whip the blood do but make it pulse more vigorously.

author: Nathaniel Branden
title: For the rational, psychologically healthy man, the desire for pleasure is the desire to celebrate his control over reality. For the neurotic, the desire for pleasure is the desire to escape from reality.

author: Bertolt Brecht
title: For the villainy of the world is great, and a man has to run his legs off to keep them from being stolen out fom underneath him.

author: Lao-Tzu
title: For the wise man looks into space and he knows there is no limited dimensions.

author: Friedrich Nietzsche
title: For the woman, the man is a means: the end is always the child.

author: Aeschylus
title: For there is no defense for a man who, in the excess of his wealth, has kicked the great altar of Justice out of sight.

author: Aeschylus
title: For this is the mark of a wise and upright man, not to rail against the gods in misfortune.

author: Marshall Mcluhan
title: For tribal man space was the uncontrollable mystery. For technological man it is time that occupies the same role.

author: Herman Melville
title: For whatever is truly wondrous and fearful in man, never yet was put into words or books.

author: Mark Twain
title: Fortune knocks at every man's door once in a life, but in a good many cases the man is in a neighboring saloon and does not hear her.

author: Alfred de Vigny
title: France, for example, loves at the same time history and the drama, because the one explores the vast destinies of humanity, and the other the individual lot of man.

author: Hubert Humphrey
title: Freedom is the most contagious virus known to man.,

author: Hubert H. Humphrey
title: Freedom is the most contagious virus known to man.

author: Archibald MacLeish
title: Freedom is the right to one's dignity as a man.

author: Charles Edward Jerningham
title: Frequently, the extraordinary man is only the ordinary man in extraordinary circumstances.

author: Camille Paglia
title: Freud says, Man fears that his strength will be taken from him by woman, dreads becoming infected with her femininity and then proving himself a weakling. Masculinity must fight off effeminacy day by day. Woman and nature stand ever ready to reduce the male to boy and infant.

author: Beilby Porteus
title: Friend to the wretch whom every friend forsakes, I woo thee, Death! Life and its joys I leave to those that prize them. Hear me, 0 gracious God! At Thy good time let Death approach; I reck not, let him but come in genuine form, not with Thy vengeance armed, too much for man to bear.

author: August Strindberg
title: Friendship can only exist between persons with similar interests and points of view. Man and woman by the conventions of society are born with different interests and different points of view.

author: Marguerite Duras
title: Frigidity is desire imagined by a woman who doesn't desire the man offering himself to her. It's the desire of a woman for a man who hasn't yet come to her, whom she doesn't yet know. She's faithful to this stranger even before she belongs to him. Frigidity is the non-desire for whatever is not him.

author: Immanuel Kant
title: From such crooked wood as that which man is made of, nothing straight can be fashioned.

author: Publilius Syrus
title: From the errors of others a wise man corrects his own.

author: Margot Asquith
title: From the happy expression on their faces you might have supposed that they welcomed the war. I have met with men who loved stamps, and stones, and snakes, but I could not imagine any man loving war.

author: Ayn Rand
title: From the smallest necessity to the highest religious abstraction, from the wheel to the skyscraper, everything we are and everything we have comes from one attribute of man - the function of his reasoning mind.

author: Alfred de Vigny
title: From this, without doubt, sprang the fable. Man created it thus, because it was not given him to see more than himself and nature, which surrounds him; but he created it true with a truth all its own.

author: Abdus Salam
title: From time immemorial, man has desired to comprehend the complexity of nature in terms of as few elementary concepts as possible.

author: Albert Bushnell Hart
title: From William of Orange to William Pitt the younger there was but one man without whom English history must have taken a different turn, and that was William Pitt the elder.

author: Algernon Sidney
title: Fruits are always of the same nature with the seeds and roots from which they come, and trees are known by the fruits they bear: as a man begets a man, and a beast a beast, that society of men which constitutes a government upon the foundation of justice.

author: Eric Butterworth
title: Fundamentalists believe Jesus was God becoming man. I believe that Jesus was man becoming God.

author: Kofi Annan
title: Gather the five virtues (Dignity, Confidence, Courage, Compassion, and Faith). Then you are a man.

author: Bertolt Brecht
title: General, man is very useful. , He can fly and he can kill. , But he has one defect: , He can think.

author: John Gray
title: Generally speaking, when a woman offers unsolicited advice or tries to help a man, she has no idea of how critical and unloving he may sound to him.

author: Marlene Dietrich
title: Gentleman. A man who buys two of the same morning paper from the doorman of his favorite nightclub when he leaves with his girl.

author: Theodore Roosevelt
title: Get action. Seize the moment. Man was never intended to become an oyster.,

author: Zsa Zsa Gabor
title: Getting divorced just because you don't love a man is almost as silly as getting married just because you do.

author: Louisa May Alcott
title: Girls are so queer you never know what they mean. They say No when they mean Yes, and drive a man out of his wits for the fun of it.

author: Bill Owen
title: Give a man a beer, waste an hour. Teach a man to brew, and waste a lifetime!

author: C. Neil Strait
title: Give a man a dollar and you cheer his heart. Give him a dream and you challenge his heart. Give him Christ and you change his heart. Then the dollar and the dream become meaningful to him, and to others.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Give a man health and a course to steer; and he'll never stop to trouble about whether he's happy or not.

author: William Shakespeare
title: Give every man your ear, but few thy voice. Take each man's censure, but reserve thy judgment.

author: Dwight L. Moody
title: Give me a man who says, ''This one thing I do,'' and not, ''These fifty things, I dabble in.

author: James Cash Penney
title: Give me a stock clerk with a goal and I'll give you a man who will make history. Give me a man with no goals and I'll give you a stock clerk.

author: Henry Louis Mencken
title: Giving every man a vote has no more made men wise and free than Christianity has made them good.

author: Ezra Pound
title: Gloom and solemnity are entirely out of place in even the most rigorous study of an art originally intended to make glad the heart of man.

author: A. C. Swinburne
title: Glory to Man in the highest! For Man is the master of things.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Go into the street, and give one man a lecture on morality, and another a shilling, and see which will respect you most.

author: Horace Greeley
title: Go West, young man, and grow up with the country.

author: Benjamin Harrison
title: God forbid that the day should ever come when, in the American mind, the thought of man as a consumer shall submerge the old American thought of man as a creature of God, endowed with unalienable rights.

author: Benjamin Franklin
title: God grant that not only the love of liberty but a thorough knowledge of the rights of man may pervade all the nations of the earth, so that a philosopher may set his foot anywhere on its surface and say: This is my country!

author: Antonio Porchia
title: God has given a great deal to man, but man would like something from man.

author: Helen Keller
title: God himself is not secure, having given man dominion over his work.

author: Algernon Sydney
title: God leaves to Man the choice of Forms in Government; and those who constitute one Form, may abrogate it.

author: Aeschylus
title: God lends a helping hand to the man who tries hard.

author: Christopher Morley
title: God made man merely to hear some praise of what he'd done on those Five Days.

author: Henry Ward Beecher
title: God made man to go by motives, and he will not go without them, any more than a boat without steam or a balloon without gas.

author: William Cowper
title: God made the country and man made the town.

author: C. S. Lewis
title: God made us: invented us as a man invents an engine. A car is made to run on petrol, and it would not run properly on anything else. Now God designed the human machine to run on Himself.

author: Thomas Fuller
title: God makes, and apparel shapes; but it's money that finishes the man.

author: Abraham Lincoln
title: God must love the common man, he made so many of them.

author: Bob Marley
title: God sent me on earth. He send me to do something, and nobody can stop me. If God want to stop me, then I stop. Man never can.

author: Arthur Young
title: God sleeps in the minerals, awakens in plants, walks in animals, and thinks in man.

author: William Lyon Phelps
title: God speaks to me not through the thunder and the earthquake, nor through the ocean and the stars, but through the Son of Man, and speaks in a language adapted to my imperfect sight and hearing.

author: Alfred Adler
title: God who is eternally complete, who directs the stars, who is the master of fates, who elevates man from his lowliness to Himself, who speaks from the cosmos to every single human soul, is the most brilliant manifestation of the goal of perfection.

author: Benjamin Franklin
title: God works wonders now and then; Behold a lawyer, an honest man.

author: Abraham Cahan
title: God, for example, appealed to me as a beardless man wearing a quilted silk cap; holiness was something burning, forbidding, something connected with fire while a day had the form of an oblong box.

author: Berthold Auerbach
title: Good and stupid, is a common saying. I have found that only the judicious are really good. Only clever men know what is good for others; and at the first appearance of disadvantage to himself, the stupid man deserts.

author: Anne Boleyn
title: Good Christian people, I am come hither to die, for according to the law, and by the law I am judged to die, and therefore I will speak nothing against it. I am come hither to accuse no man, nor to speak anything of that, whereof I am accused and condemned to die.

author: Henry Louis Mencken
title: Government is actually the worst failure of civilized man. There has never been a really good one, and even those that are most tolerable are arbitrary, cruel, grasping and unintelligent.

author: Desiderius Erasmus
title: Great abundance of riches cannot be gathered and kept by any man without sin.

author: Adam Smith
title: Great ambition, the desire of real superiority, of leading and directing, seems to be altogether peculiar to man, and speech is the great instrument of ambition.

author: Winston Churchill
title: Great and good are seldom the same man.

author: Dylan Thomas
title: Great is the hand that holds dominion over man by a scribbled name.

author: Carl von Clausewitz
title: Great things alone can make a great mind, and petty things will make a petty mind unless a man rejects them as completely alien.

author: André Maurois
title: Growing old is no more than a bad habit which a busy man has no time to form.

author: André Maurois
title: Growing old is no more than a bad habit which a busy man has no time to form.

author: B. B. King
title: Growing up, I was taught that a man has to defend his family. When the wolf is trying to get in, you gotta stand in the doorway.

author: Mark Twain
title: Habit is habit, and not to be flung out of the window by any man, but coaxed downstairs a step at a time.

author: Evenus
title: Habit, my friend, is practice long pursued, that at last becomes man himself.

author: Thomas Malthus
title: Had population and food increased in the same ratio, it is probable that man might never have emerged from the savage state.

author: Henry van Dyke
title: Half of the secular unrest and dismal, profane sadness of modern society comes from the vain ideas that every man is bound to be a critic for life.

author: Fred Allen
title: Hanging is too good for a man who makes puns; he should be drawn and quoted.

author: Benjamin Franklin
title: Happiness consists more in small conveniences of pleasures that occur every day, than in great pieces of good fortune that happen but seldom to a man in the course of his life.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Happy is the man who can make a living by his hobby.

author: Ovid
title: Happy is the man who has broken the chains which hurt the mind, and has given up worrying once and for all.

author: Edward Bulwer-Lytton
title: Happy is the man who hath never known what it is to taste of fame -to have it is a purgatory, to want it is a Hell!

author: Midrash
title: Happy is the man whose deeds are greater than his learning

author: Lord Mancroft
title: Happy is the man with a wife to tell him what to do and a secretary to do it.

author: Seneca
title: Happy the man who can endure the highest and the lowest fortune. He, who has endured such vicissitudes with equanimity, has deprived misfortune of its power.

author: Alexander Pope
title: Happy the man whose wish and care a few paternal acres bound, content to breathe his native air in his own ground.

author: John Dryden
title: Happy the man, and happy he alone, he who can call today his own; he who, secure within, can say, tomorrow do thy worst, for I have lived today.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Has fear ever held a man back from anything he really wanted?

author: Homer
title: Hateful to me as the gates of Hades is that man who hides one thing in his heart and speaks another.

author: James Baldwin
title: Hatred, which could destroy so much, never failed to destroy the man who hated, and this was an immutable law.

author: Marcus Tullius Cicero
title: He does not seem to me to be a free man who does not sometimes do nothing.

author: Ada Leverson
title: He had no special hobbies, but he needed luxury in general of a kind, and especially the luxury of getting things in a hurry, his theory being that everything comes to the man who won't wait.

author: Voltaire
title: He is a hard man who is only just, and a sad one who is only wise.

author: Winston Churchill
title: He is a modest little man who has a good deal to be modest about.

author: Epictetus
title: He is a wise man who does not grieve for the things which he has not, but rejoices for those which he has.

author: William Shakespeare
title: He is half of a blessed man. Left to be finished by such as she; and she a fair divided excellence, whose fullness of perfection lies in him.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: He is no wise man who will quit a certainty for an uncertainty.

author: William Ellery Channing
title: He is to be educated not because he's to make shoes, nails, and pins, but because he is a man.

author: Johann Kaspar Lavater
title: He knows very little of mankind who expects, by any facts or reasoning, to convince a determined party man.

author: James Baldwin
title: He may be a very nice man. But I haven't got the time to figure that out. All I know is, he's got a uniform and a gun and I have to relate to him that way. That's the only way to relate to him because one of us may have to die.

author: John Donne
title: He must pull out his own eyes, and see no creature, before he can say, he sees no God; He must be no man, and quench his reasonable soul, before he can say to himself, there is no God.

author: Abraham Lincoln
title: He reminds me of the man who murdered both his parents, and then when the sentence was about to be pronounced, pleaded for mercy on the grounds that he was orphan.

author: Thomas Fuller
title: He that falls into sin is a man; that grieves at it, is a saint; that boasteth of it, is a devil.

author: William Shakespeare
title: He that hath a beard is more than a youth, and he that hath no beard is less than a man.

author: Jeremy Taylor
title: He that speaketh against his own reason speaks against his own conscience, and therefore it is certain that no man serves God with a good conscience who serves him against his reason.

author: Charles Caleb Colton
title: He that thinks he is the happiest man, really is so. But he that thinks he is the wisest, is generally the greatest fool.

author: Jonathan Swift
title: He was a bold man that first ate an oyster.

author: Mario Puzo
title: He was a degenerate gambler. That is, a man who gambled simply to gamble and must lose. As a hero who goes to war must die. Show me a gambler and I'll show you a loser, show me a hero and I'll show you a corpse.

author: Joseph Heller
title: He was a self-made man who owed his lack of success to nobody.

author: Alexis de Tocqueville
title: He was as great as a man can be without morality.

author: Buddha
title: He who gives away shall have real gain. He who subdues himself shall be free; he shall cease to be a slave of passions. The righteous man casts off evil, and by rooting out lust, bitterness, and illusion do we reach Nirvana.

author: Antoine de Saint-Exupery
title: He who has gone, so we but cherish his memory, abides with us, more potent, nay, more present than the living man.

author: Herman Melville
title: He who has never failed somewhere, that man can not be great.

author: St. John of the Cross
title: He who interrupts the course of his spiritual exercises and prayer is like a man who allows a bird to escape from his hand; he can hardly catch it again.

author: Tad Williams
title: He who is certain he knows the ending of things when he is only beginning them is either extremely wise or extremely foolish; no matter which is true, he is certainly an unhappy man, for he has put a knife in the heart of wonder.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: He who makes a beast of himself gets rid of the pain of being a man.

author: Anna C. Brackett
title: He who receives a great many letters demanding answer, sees himself as if engaged in a hopeless struggle of one man against the rest of the world.

author: George Berkeley
title: He who says there is no such thing as an honest man, you may be sure is himself a knave.

author: Blaise Pascal
title: He who will know fully the vanity of man has only to consider the causes and effects of love.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: He who would be a man must therefore be a non-conformist.

author: William Wycherley
title: He's a fool that marries, but he's a greater that does not marry a fool; what is wit in a wife good for, but to make a man a cuckold?

author: Clarence Darrow
title: He's the greatest man who ever came out of Plymouth, Vermont. [On Calvin Coolidge]

author: Bill Flores
title: Healthy marriages are the ones between a man and a woman because they can have a healthy family, and they can raise children in a way that's best for their future, not only socially but psychologically, economically, from a health perspective.

author: Joseph Rudyard Kipling
title: Heaven grant us patience with a man in love.

author: Henry Ward Beecher
title: Heaven will be inherited by every man who has heaven in his soul.

author: Lyndon B. Johnson
title: Heck by the time a man scratches his behind, clears his throat, and tells me how smart he is, we've already wasted fifteen minutes.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Hegel was right when he said that we learn from history that man can never learn anything from history.

author: Horace
title: Help a man against his will and you do the same as murder him.

author: Ogden Nash
title: Here is a pen and here is a pencil, here's a typewriter, here's a stencil, here's a list of today's appointments, and all the flies in all the ointments, the daily woes that a man endures - take them, George, they're yours!

author: Anna Quindlen
title: Here is the real domino theory - gay man to gay man, bisexual man to straight woman, addict mother to newborn baby, they all fall down and someday it will come to you.

author: Andrew Carnegie
title: Here lies a man who knew how to enlist in his service better men than himself.

author: Epitaph
title: Here lies one believe it if you can, who thought an attorney, was a honest man.

author: Earl Rochester
title: Here lies our Sovereign Lord, the King whose word no man relies on: He never said a foolish thing nor ever did a wise one.

author: G. C. Lichtenberg
title: Here take back the stuff that I am, nature, knead it back into the dough of being, make of me a bush, a cloud, whatever you will, even a man, only no longer make me.

author: Calvin Coolidge
title: Heroism is not only in the man, but in the occasion.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: Heroism is the divine relation which, in all times, unites a great man to other men.

author: Breaux Greer
title: Hey, man, I toss a stick for a living. Gotta spice up that deal, y'know. Gotta stand out.

author: Bob Dylan
title: Hey, Mr. Tambourine Man, play a song for me. , I'm not sleepy and there is no place I'm going to. , Hey, Mr. Tambourine Man, play a song for me. , In the jingle-jangle morning, I'll come following you.

author: Bertolt Brecht
title: High above the lake a bomber flies. , From the rowing boats , Children look up, women, an old man. From a distance , They appear like young starlings, their beaks , Wide open for food.

author: John A. Hannah
title: Higher education must lead the march back to the fundamentals of human relationships, to the old discovery that is ever new, that man does not live by bread alone.

author: A. E. Housman
title:
His folly has not fellow ,
 Beneath the blue of day ,
 That gives to man or woman ,
 His heart and soul away.

author: Emily Dickinson
title: His mind of man, a secret makes I meet him with a start he carries a circumference in which I have no part.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: His scorn of the great is repeated too often to be real; no man thinks much of that which he despises.

author: Malcolm X
title: History proves that the white man is a devil.,

author: Oswald Chambers
title: Holiness, not happiness, is the chief end of man.

author: Stephen Vincent Benét
title: Honesty is as rare as a man without self-pity.

author: Richard Whately
title: Honesty is the best policy; but he who is governed by that maxim is not an honest man.

author: Arthur Schopenhauer
title: Honor means that a man is not exceptional; fame, that he is. Fame is something which must be won; honor, only something which must not be lost.

author: Aristotle
title: Hope is the dream of a waking man.

author: Francois de la Rochefoucauld
title: Hope is the last thing that dies in man; and though it be exceedingly deceitful, yet it is of this good use to us, that while we are traveling through life it conducts us in an easier and more pleasant way to our journey's end.

author: Alexander Pope
title: Hope springs eternal in the human breast: Man never is, but always To be Blest.

author: Lord Chesterfield
title: Horse-play, romping, frequent and loud fits of laughter, jokes, and indiscriminate familiarity, will sink both merit and knowledge into a degree of contempt. They compose at most a merry fellow; and a merry fellow was never yet a respectable man.

author: Babe Ruth
title: How about a little noise. How do you expect a man to putt?

author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow
title: How beautiful is youth! how bright it gleams with its illusions, aspirations, dreams! Book of Beginnings, Story without End, Each maid a heroine, and each man a friend!

author: Oscar Wilde
title: How can a woman be expected to be happy with a man who insists on treating her as if she were a perfectly normal human being.

author: William James

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: How can you dare teach a man to read until you've taught him everything else first?

author: Aleksandr Solzjenitsyn
title: How can you expect a man who's warm to understand one who's cold?

author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
title: How could there be any question of acquiring or possessing, when the one thing needful for a man is to become - to be at last, and to die in the fullness of his being.

author: Lois McMaster Bujold
title: How could you be a Great Man if history brought you no Great Events, or brought you to them at the wrong time, too young, too old?

author: Benjamin Robert Haydon
title: How difficult it is to get men to believe that any other man can or does act from disinterestedness.

author: Søren Kierkegaard
title: How ironical that it is by means of speech that man can degrade himself below the level of dumb creation - for a chatterbox is truly of a lower category than a dumb creature.

author: Ovid
title: How little is the promise of the child fulfilled in the man.

author: Edward Bulwer-Lytton
title: How little praise warms out of a man the good that is in him, as the sneer of contempt which he feels is unjust chill the ardor to excel.

author: Elbert Hubbard
title: How many a man has thrown up his hands at a time when a little more effort, a little more patience would have achieved success?

author: Marcus Aurelius
title: How ridiculous and unrealistic is the man who is astonished at anything that happens in life.

author: Agatha Christie
title: How true is the saying that man was forced to invent work in order to escape the strain of having to think.

author: Anais Nin
title: How wrong it is for a woman to expect the man to build the world she wants, rather than to create it herself.

author: Caryl Chessman
title: How, possibly, could the police have made the 'mistake' of charging the wrong man with the notorious Red Light Bandit crimes? That also is something that is fully revealed in the Pandora's Box of facts I have prepared.

author: Quentin Crisp
title: However low a man sinks he never reaches the level of the police.

author: Raymond Chandler
title: However toplofty and idealistic a man may be, he can always rationalize his right to earn money.

author: Adam Clarke
title: However, all gifts seem now to be absorbed in one and a man must be either a Preacher or nothing.

author: Adam Smith
title: Humanity is the virtue of a woman, generosity that of a man.

title: Humans are imperfect. That's one of the reasons that classical and jazz are in trouble. We're on the quest for the perfect performance and every note has to be right. Man, every note is not right in life.

author: Dwight D. Eisenhower
title: Humility must always be the portion of any man who receives acclaim earned in the blood of his followers and the sacrifices of his friends.

author: Leo Tolstoy

author: William Somerset Maugham
title: Hypocrisy is the most difficult and nerve-racking vice that any man can pursue; it needs an unceasing vigilance and a rare detachment of spirit. It cannot, like adultery or gluttony, be practiced at spare moments; it is a whole-time job.

author: Marcus Tullius Cicero

title: I always remember an epitaph which is in the cemetery at Tombstone, Arizona. It says: ''Here lies Jack Williams. He done his damnedest.'' I think that is the greatest epitaph a man can have.

author: Vladimir Ilyich Lenin
title: I am a bad, wicked man, but I am practicing moral self-purification; I don't eat meat any more, I now eat rice cutlets.

author: Javier Perez de Cuellar
title: I am a free man. I feel as light as a feather.

author: Clarence Darrow
title: I am a friend of the working man, and I would rather be his friend, than be one.

author: C. Colman
title: I am a handsome man, but I'm a gay deceiver.

author: William Shakespeare
title: I am a man more sinned against than sinning.

author: Zsa Zsa Gabor
title: I am a marvelous housekeeper. Every time I leave a man I keep his house.

author: Malcolm X
title: I am a Muslim and my religion makes me be against all forms of racism. It keeps me from judging any man by the color of his skin. It teaches me to judge him by his deeds .

author: Abraham Lincoln
title: I am a patient man - always willing to forgive on the Christian terms of repentance; and also to give ample time for repentance. Still I must save this government if possible.

author: Josh Billings
title: I am a poor man, but I have this consolation: I am poor by accident, not by design.

author: Lord George Byron
title: I am about to be married, and am of course in all the misery of a man in pursuit of happiness.

author: Andrew Cohen
title: I am already inherently full and complete as I am. Man doesn't need woman and woman doesn't need man in order to experience his or her inherent fullness.

author: William Wordsworth
title: I am already kindly disposed towards you. My friendship it is not in my power to give: this is a gift which no man can make, it is not in our own power: a sound and healthy friendship is the growth of time and circumstance, it will spring up and thrive li

author: Ralph Ellison
title: I am an invisible man. I am a man of substance, of flesh and bone, fiber and liquids - and I might even be said to possess a mind. I am invisible, understand, simply because people refuse to see me.

author: Mark Twain
title: I am an old man and have known a great many sorrows, but most of them never happened.

author: James Baldwin
title: I am aware that no man is a villain in his own eyes.

title: I am convinced that a light supper, a good night's sleep, and a fine morning, have sometimes made a hero of the same man, who, by an indigestion, a restless night, and rainy morning, would have proved a coward.

title: I am going to stop calling you a white man and I'm going to ask you to stop calling me a black man.,

title: I am more and more convinced that man is a dangerous creature and that power, whether vested in many or a few, is ever grasping, and like the grave, cries, 'Give, give.

title: I am the inferior of any man whose rights I trample under foot.

title: I am truly horrified by modern man. Such absence of feeling, such narrowness of outlook, such lack of passion and information, such feebleness of thought.

title: I believe in the brotherhood of man, all men, but I don't believe in brotherhood with anybody who doesn't want brotherhood with me. I believe in treating people right, but I'm not going to waste my time trying to treat somebody right who doesn't know how to return the treatment.

author: John D. Rockefeller
title: I believe in the dignity of labor, whether with head or hand; that the world owes no man a living but that it owes every man an opportunity to make a living.

title: I believe that a man is converted when first he hears the low, vast murmur of life, of human life, troubling his hitherto unconscious self.

author: William Faulkner
title: I believe that man will not merely endure; he will prevail.

author: Mark Twain
title: I believe that our Heavenly Father invented man because he was disappointed in the monkey.

author: Cormac McCarthy
title: I can normally tell how intelligent a man is by how stupid he thinks I am.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: I can think of no other edifice constructed by man as altruistic as a lighthouse. They were built only to serve.

author: David Herbert Lawrence
title: I can't bear art that you can walk round and admire. A book should be either a bandit or a rebel or a man in the crowd.

title: I cannot see how a man of any large degree of humorous perception can ever be religious - except he purposely shut the eyes of his mind and keep them shut by force.

title: I cannot trust a man to control others who cannot control himself.,

author: William Shakespeare
title: I care not, a man can die but once; we owe God and death.
