title: Man has lost the capacity to foresee and to forestall. He will end by destroying the earth.

author: Francesco Petrarca
title: Man has no greater enemy than himself.

author: Albert Claude
title: Man has now become an adjunct to perfect and carry forward these conquests.

author: Aleksandr Solzjenitsyn
title: Man has set for himself the goal of conquering the world but in the processes loses his soul.

author: George Gurdjieff
title: Man has the possibility of existence after death. But possibility is one thing and the realization of the possibility is quite a different thing.

author: Ludwig Wittgenstein
title: Man has to awaken to wonder - and so perhaps do peoples. Science is a way of sending him to sleep again.

author: Billy Graham
title: Man has two great spiritual needs. One is for forgiveness. The other is for goodness.

author: Oliver Wendell Holmes
title: Man has will, but woman has her way.

author: Sigmund Freud
title: Man has, as it were, become a kind of prosthetic God. When he puts on all his auxiliary organs, he is truly magnificent; but those organs have not grown on him and they still give him much trouble at times.

author: Henry Vaughan
title: Man hath still either toys or care: But hath no root, nor to one place is tied, but ever restless and irregular, about this earth doth run and ride. He knows he hath a home, but scarce knows where; He says it is so far, that he has quite forgot how to go there

author: Edward Dahlberg
title: Man hoards himself when he has nothing to give away.

author: Henry David Thoreau
title: Man identifies himself with earth or material. Spirit is strange to him: he is afraid of ghosts.

author: Joseph De Maistre
title: Man in general, if reduced to himself, is too wicked to be free.

author: Lily Tomlin
title: Man invented language to satisfy his deep need to complain.

author: Henry Louis Mencken
title: Man is a beautiful machine that works very badly.

author: Plato
title: Man is a being in search of meaning.

author: Albert Schweitzer
title: Man is a clever animal who behaves like an imbecile.

author: Gaston Bachelard
title: Man is a creation of desire, not a creation of need.

author: Mark Twain
title: Man is a creature made at the end of the week's work when God was tired.

author: Robert Louis Stevenson
title: Man is a creature who lives not upon bread alone, but principally by catch words.

author: Bertrand Russell
title: Man is a credulous animal, and must believe something; in the absence of good grounds for belief, he will be satisfied with bad ones.

author: Charles Lamb
title: Man is a gaming animal. He must always be trying to get the better in something or other.

author: Aristotle
title: Man is a goal seeking animal. His life only has meaning if he is reaching out and striving for his goals.

author: G. C. Lichtenberg
title: Man is a gregarious animal and much more so in his mind than in his body. A golden rule; judge men not by their opinions but by what their opinions have made of them.

author: Carl Sandburg
title: Man is a long time coming. , Man will yet win. , Brother may yet line up with brother: , This old anvil laughs at many broken hammers. , There are men who can't be bought.

author: William Hazlitt
title: Man is a make-believe animal - he is never so truly himself as when he is acting a part.

author: G. C. Lichtenberg
title: Man is a masterpiece of creation if for no other reason than that, all the weight of evidence for determinism notwithstanding, he believes he has free will.

author: Abraham J. Heschel
title: Man is a messenger who forgot the message.

author: Edmond and Jules de Goncourt
title: Man is a mind betrayed, not served, by his organs.

author: Henry Louis Mencken
title: Man is a natural polygamist. He always has one woman leading him by the nose and another hanging on to his coattails.

author: Thomas Browne
title: Man is a noble animal, splendid in ashes, and pompous in the grave.

author: Oscar Wilde
title: Man is a rational animal who always loses his temper when called upon to act according with the dictates of reason.

author: Alexander Hamilton
title: Man is a reasoning rather than a reasonable animal.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Man is a shrewd inventor, and is ever taking the hint of a new machine from his own structure, adapting some secret of his own anatomy in iron, wood, and leather, to some required function in the work of the world.

author: Adlai E. Stevenson
title: Man is a strange animal. He generally cannot read the handwriting on the wall until his back is up against it.

author: John Sterling
title: Man is a substance clad in shadows.

author: Benjamin Franklin
title: Man is a tool-making animal.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: Man is a tool-using animal. Without tools he is nothing, with tools he is all.

author: Carl Sagan
title: Man is a transitional animal. He is not the climax of creation.

author: Plato
title: Man is a two-legged animal without feathers.

author: Jean-Paul Sartre
title: Man is a useless passion.

author: Ogden Nash
title: Man is a victim of dope in the incurable form of hope.

author: G. C. Lichtenberg
title: Man is always partial and is quite right to be. Even impartiality is partial.

author: Aldous Huxley
title: Man is an amphibian who lives simultaneously in two worlds-the given and the home-made, the world of matter, life and consciousness and the world of symbols.

author: Adam Smith
title: Man is an animal that makes bargains; no other animal does this - one dog does not change a bone with another.

author: William S. Burroughs
title: Man is an artifact designed for space travel. He is not designed to remain in his present biologic state any more than a tadpole is designed to remain a tadpole.

author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
title: Man is an exception, whatever else he is. If he is not the image of God, then he is a disease of the dust. If it is not true that a divine being fell, then we can only say that one of the animals went entirely off its head.

author: Albert Camus
title: Man is an idea, and a precious small idea once he turns his back on love.

author: Augusto Roa Bastos
title: Man is an idiot. He doesn't know how to do anything without copying, without imitating, without plagiarizing, without aping. It might even have been that man invented generation by coitus after seeing the grasshopper copulate.

author: Gaston Bachelard
title: Man is an imagining being.

author: Aldous Huxley
title: Man is an intelligence, not served by, but in servitude to his organs.

author: Ezra Pound
title: Man is an over-complicated organism. If he is doomed to extinction he will die out for want of simplicity.

author: George Santayana
title: Man is as full of potential as he is of importance.

author: Baltasar Gracian
title: Man is born a barbarian, and only raises himself above the beast by culture.

author: Oliver Wendell Holmes
title: Man is born a predestined idealist, for he is born to act. To act is to affirm the worth of an end, and to persist in affirming the worth of an end is to make an ideal.

author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau
title: Man is born free, yet he is everywhere in chains.

author: Lord George Byron
title: Man is born passionate of body, but with an innate though secret tendency to the love of Good in his main-spring of Mind. But God help us all! It is at present a sad jar of atoms.

author: Boris Pasternak
title: Man is born to live and not to prepare to live.

author: Hans J. Morgenthau
title: Man is born to seek power, yet his actual condition makes him a slave to the power of others.

author: Aristotle
title: Man is by nature a political animal.

author: Arthur Keith
title: Man is by nature competitive, combative, ambitious, jealous, envious, and vengeful.

author: Jean-Paul Sartre
title: Man is condemned to be free; because once thrown into the world, he is responsible for everything he does.

author: Cat Stevens
title: Man is created to be God's deputy on earth and it is important to realize the obligation to rid ourselves of all illusions and to make our lives a preparation for the next life.

author: Thomas Hobbes
title: Man is distinguished, not only by his reason; but also by this singular passion from other animals... which is a lust of the mind, that by a perseverance of delight in the continual and indefatigable generation of knowledge, exceeds the short vehemence of any carnal pleasure.

author: Eric Hoffer
title: Man is eminently a storyteller. His search for a purpose, a cause, an ideal, a mission and the like is largely a search for a plot and a pattern in the development of his life story - a story that is basically without meaning or pattern.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: Man is emphatically a proselytizing creature.

author: James Thurber
title: Man is flying too fast for a world that is round. Soon he will catch up with himself in a great rear end collision.

author: Voltaire
title: Man is free at the moment he wishes to be.

author: Samuel Butler
title: Man is God's highest present development. He is the latest thing in God.

author: Buckminster Fuller
title: Man is going to be displaced altogether as a specialist by the computer. Man himself is being forced to reestablish, employ, and enjoy his innate comprehensivity. Coping with the totality of Spaceship Earth and universe is ahead for all of us.

author: René Daumal
title: Man is head, chest and stomach. Each of these animals operates, more often than not, individually. I eat, I feel, I even, although rarely, think. This jungle crawls and teems, is hungry, roars, gets angry, devours itself, and its cacophonic concert does not even stop when you are asleep.

author: Joseph De Maistre
title: Man is insatiable for power; he is infantile in his desires and, always discontented with what he has, loves only what he has not. People complain of the despotism of princes; they ought to complain of the despotism of man.

author: Oscar Wilde
title: Man is least himself when he talks in his own person. Give him a mask, and he will tell you the truth.

author: Henry S. Haskins
title: Man is liberated from his illusions to make room for a fresh set.

author: Oscar Wilde
title: Man is made for something better than disturbing dirt.

author: James Allen
title: Man is made or unmade by himself. By the right choice he ascends. As a being of power, intelligence, and love, and the lord of his own thoughts, he holds the key to every situation.

author: Benjamin Disraeli
title: Man is made to adore and to obey: but if you will not command him, if you give him nothing to worship, he will fashion his own divinities, and find a chieftain in his own passions.

author: Karl Wilhelm Von Humboldt
title: Man is more disposed to domination than freedom; and a structure of dominion not only gladdens the eye of the master who rears and protects it, but even its servants are uplifted by the thought that they are members of a whole, which rises high above the life and strength of single generations.

author: Benjamin Disraeli
title: Man is more powerful than matter.

author: W.S. Gilbert
title: Man is Nature's sole mistake.

author: Friedrich Nietzsche
title: Man is no longer an artist, he has become a work of art.

author: Norman Cousins
title: Man is not imprisoned by habit. Great changes in him can be wrought by crisis - once that crisis can be recognized and understood.

author: John Dewey
title: Man is not logical and his intellectual history is a record of mental reserves and compromises. He hangs on to what he can in his old beliefs even when he is compelled to surrender their logical basis.

author: Ernest Hemingway
title: Man is not made for defeat.

author: John Donne
title: Man is not only a contributory creature, but a total creature; he does not only make one, but he is all; he is not a piece of the world, but the world itself; and next to the glory of God, the reason why there is a world.

author: Benjamin Disraeli
title: Man is not the creature of circumstances, circumstances are the creatures of men. We are free agents, and man is more powerful than matter.

author: Betty Friedan
title: Man is not the enemy here, but the fellow victim.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Man is not weak; knowledge is more than equivalent to force.

author: André Malraux
title: Man is not what he thinks he is, he is what he hides.

author: Blaise Pascal
title: Man is obviously made for thinking. Therein lies all his dignity and his merit; and his whole duty is to think as he ought.

author: Benjamin Disraeli
title: Man is only truly great when he acts from his passions.

author: Alfred A. Montapert
title: Man is raw and wild, that is one of the reasons why he needs the Christian teaching.

author: Jean de la Fontaine
title: Man is so made that when anything fires his soul, impossibilities vanish

author: Joseph De Maistre
title: Man is so muddled, so dependent on the things immediately before his eyes, that every day even the most submissive believer can be seen to risk the torments of the afterlife for the smallest pleasure.

author: Michel Eyquem De Montaigne
title: Man is stark mad; he cannot make a flea, and yet he will be making gods by the dozens.

author: David Sarnoff
title: Man is still the greatest miracle and the greatest problem on this earth.

author: John F. Kennedy
title: Man is still the most extraordinary computer of all.

author: Bill Vaughan
title: Man is the animal that intends to shoot himself out into interplanetary space, after having given up on the problem of an efficient way to get himself five miles to work and back each day.

author: Henry David Thoreau
title: Man is the artificer of his own happiness.

author: Wernher von Braun
title: Man is the best computer we can put aboard a spacecraft... and the only one that can be mass produced with unskilled labor.

author: Remy de Gourmont
title: Man is the inventor of stupidity.

author: Erich Fromm
title: Man is the only animal for whom his own existence is a problem which he has to solve.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Man is the only animal of which I am thoroughly and cravenly afraid... There is no harm in a well-fed lion. It has no ideals, no sect, no party.

author: Mark Twain
title: Man is the only animal that blushes - or needs to.

author: Samuel Butler
title: Man is the only animal that laughs and has a state legislature.

author: William Hazlitt
title: Man is the only animal that laughs and weeps; for he is the only animal that is struck with the difference between what things are and what they might of been.

author: Jean Kerr
title: Man is the only animal that learns by being hypocritical. He pretends to be polite and then, eventually, he becomes polite.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Man is the only animal which esteems itself rich in proportion to the number and voracity of its parasites.

author: George Orwell
title: Man is the only creature that consumes without producing.

author: Eric Hoffer
title: Man is the only creature that strives to surpass himself, and yearns for the impossible.

author: Mark Twain
title: Man is the only creature who has a nasty mind.

author: Albert Camus
title: Man is the only creature who refuses to be what he is.

author: Ayn Rand
title: Man is the only living species that has the power to act as his own destroyer—and that is the way he has acted through most of his history.

author: H.G. Wells
title: Man is the unnatural animal, the rebel child of nature, and more and more does he turn himself against the harsh and fitful hand that reared him.

author: G. C. Lichtenberg
title: Man is to be found in reason, God in the passions.

author: Blaise Pascal
title: Man is to himself the most wonderful object in nature; for he cannot conceive what the body is, still less what the mind is, and least of all how a body should be united to a mind. This is the consummation of his difficulties, and yet it is his very being.

author: Anton Chekhov
title: Man is what he believes.

author: Alfred Adler
title: Man know much more than he understands.

author: Alfred Adler
title: Man knows more than he understands.

author: Alfred Adler
title: Man knows much more than he understands.,

author: Richard Buckminster Fuller
title: Man knows so much and does so little.

author: André Malraux
title: Man knows that the world is not made on a human scale; and he wishes that it were.

author: Leo Tolstoy
title: Man lives consciously for himself, but is an unconscious instrument in the attainment of the historic, universal, aims of humanity.

author: William James
title: Man lives for science as well as bread.

author: G. C. Lichtenberg
title: Man loves company, even if it is only that of a smoldering candle.

author: Blaise Pascal
title: Man loves malice, but not against one-eyed men nor the unfortunate, but against the fortunate and proud.

author: Maxwell Maltz
title: Man maintains his balance, poise, and sense of security only as he is moving forward.

author: Ernest Renan
title: Man makes holy what he believes.

author: Jacob Bronowski
title: Man masters nature not by force but by understanding. This is why science has succeeded where magic failed: because it has looked for no spell to cast over nature.

author: Adam Clarke
title: Man may be considered as having a twofold origin - natural, which is common and the same to all - patronymic, which belongs to the various families of which the whole human race is composed.

author: Erich Fromm
title: Man may be defined as the animal that can say ''I,'' that can be aware of himself as a separate entity.

author: William Cowper
title: Man may dismiss compassion from his heart, but God never will.

author: Menander of Athens
title: Man must be prepared for every event of life, for there is nothing that is durable.

author: Albert Schweitzer
title: Man must cease attributing his problems to his environment, and learn again to exercise his will - his personal responsibility.

author: Arthur Miller
title: Man must shape his tools lest they shape him.,

author: E. M. Cioran
title: Man must vanquish himself, must do himself violence, in order to perform the slightest action untainted by evil.

author: Carl Gustav Jung
title: Man needs difficulties; they are necessary for health.

author: Abdul Kalam
title: Man needs his difficulties because they are necessary to enjoy success.

author: Bertrand Russell
title: Man needs, for his happiness, not only the enjoyment of this or that, but hope and enterprise and change.

author: Bernard Williams
title: Man never made any material as resilient as the human spirit.

author: Fjodor M. Dostojewski
title: Man only likes to count his troubles, but he does not count his joys.

author: Friedrich von Schiller
title: Man only plays when in the full meaning of the word he is a man, and he is only completely a man when he plays.

author: Robert Browning
title: Man partly is and wholly hopes to be.

author: Thomas à Kempis
title: Man proposes, but God disposes.

author: Milan Kundera
title: Man reckons with immortality, and forgets to reckon with death.

author: Jean Cocteau
title: Man seeks to escape himself in myth, and does so by any means at his disposal. Drugs, alcohol, or lies. Unable to withdraw into himself, he disguises himself. Lies and inaccuracy give him a few moments of comfort.

author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
title: Man seems to be capable of great virtues but not of small virtues; capable of defying his torturer but not of keeping his temper.

author: Rene Dubos
title: Man shapes himself through decision that shape his environment.

author: Anthony Eden
title: Man should be master of his environment, not its slave. That is what freedom means.

author: William Ewart Gladstone
title: Man should beware of letting his religion spoil his morality.

author: Thomas De Quincey
title: Man should forget his anger before he lies down to sleep.

author: Antoine Rivarol
title: Man spends his life in reasoning on the past, in complaining of the present, in fearing future.

author: Eric Hoffer
title: Man staggers through life yapped at by his reason, pulled and shoved by his appetites, whispered to by fears, beckoned by hopes. Small wonder that what he craves most is self-forgetting.

author: Alcuin of York
title: Man thinks, God directs.

author: Henry Miller
title: Man torturing man is a fiend beyond description. You turn a corner in the dark and there he is. You congeal into a bundle of inanimate fear. You become the very soul of anesthesia. But there is no escaping him. It is your turn now...

author: Albert Einstein
title: Man tries to make for himself in the fashion that suits him best a simplified and intelligible picture of the world; he then tries to some extent to substitute this cosmos of his for the world of experience, and thus to overcome it.

author: Abraham Myerson
title: Man uses his intelligence less in the care of his own species than he does in his care of anything else he owns or governs.

author: Albert Camus
title: Man wants to live, but it is useless to hope that this desire will dictate all his actions.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Man was born to be rich, or grow rich by use of his faculties, by the union of thought with nature. Property is an intellectual production. The game requires coolness, right reasoning, promptness, and patience in the players.

author: Henry Wheeler Shaw
title: Man was created a little lower than the angels and has bin getting a little lower ever since.

author: Ralph Ransom
title: Man was created as a being who should constantly keep improving, a being who on reaching one goal sets a higher one.

author: William Blackstone
title: Man was formed for society.

author: Pearl S. Buck
title: Man was lost if he went to a usurer, for the interest ran faster than a tiger upon him.

author: Mark Twain
title: Man was made at the end of the week's work when God was tired.

author: Eric Hoffer
title: Man was nature's mistake - she neglected to finish him - and she has never ceased paying for her mistake.

author: Conor Cruise O'Brien
title: Man watches his history on the screen with apathy and an occasional passing flicker of horror or indignation.

author: Henry Louis Mencken
title: Man weeps to think that he will die so soon; woman, that she was born so long ago.

author: Doris Lessing
title: Man who is he? Too bad, to be the work of God: Too good for the work of chance!

author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
title: Man who man would be, must rule the empire of himself.

author: Confucius
title: Man who stand on hill with mouth open will wait long time for roast duck to drop in.

author: Mark Twain
title: Man will do many things to get himself loved; he will do all things to get himself envied.

author: Hans J. Morgenthau
title: Man will not live without answers to his questions.

author: Winston Churchill
title: Man will occasionally stumble over the truth, but most of the time he will pick himself up and continue on.

author: Antonio Machado
title: Man would be otherwise. That is the essence of the specifically human.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Man's inhumanity to man is only surpassed by his cruelty to animals.

author: Marquis de Sade
title: Man's natural character is to imitate; that of the sensitive man is to resemble as closely as possible the person whom he loves. It is only by imitating the vices of others that I have earned my misfortunes.

author: Abraham J. Heschel
title: Man's sin is in his failure to live what he is. Being the master of the earth, man forgets that he is the servant of God.

author: Ayn Rand
title: Man's unique reward, however, is that while animals survive by adjusting themselves to their background, man survives by adjusting his background to himself.

author: Napoleon Hill
title: Man, alone, has the power to transform his thoughts into physical reality; man, alone, can dream and make his dreams come true.,

author: Adam Smith
title: Man, an animal that makes bargains.

author: Elie Wiesel
title: Man, as long as he lives, is immortal. One minute before his death he shall be immortal. But one minute later, God wins.

author: John Kenneth Galbraith
title: Man, at least when educated, is a pessimist. He believes it safer not to reflect on his achievements; Jove is known to strike such people down.

author: Lord George Byron
title: Man, being reasonable, must get drunk; the best of life is but intoxication.

author: Lillian Smith
title: Man, born of woman, has found it a hard thing to forgive her for giving him birth. The patriarchal protest against the ancient matriarch has borne strange fruit through the years.

author: Billy Bob Thornton
title: Man, I was drowning in sadness. And Angelina, she lifted me right up out of there.

author: Louis Armstrong
title: Man, if you gotta ask you'll never know.

author: Louis Armstrong
title: Man, if you have to ask what jazz is, you'll never know!

author: Adam Ferguson
title: Man, in his animal capacity, is qualified to subsist in every climate.

author: Albert Claude
title: Man, like other organisms, is so perfectly coordinated that he may easily forget, whether awake or asleep, that he is a colony of cells in action, and that it is the cells which achieve, through him, what he has the illusion of accomplishing himself.

author: William Shakespeare
title: Man, proud man, drest in a little brief authority, most ignorant of what he's most assur d, glassy essence, like an angry ape, plays such fantastic tricks before high heaven, as make the angels weep.

author: Bono
title: Mandela's heroism is the heroism of a man who suffered so badly for what he thought of as freedom. And yet when he had the upper hand he has this incredible self-control and these incredible leadership qualities.

author: Basil of Caesarea
title: Many a man curses the rain that falls upon his head, and knows that it brings abundance to drive away hunger.

author: Friedrich Nietzsche
title: Many a man fails as an original thinker simply because his memory it too good.

author: Maurice Chevalier
title: Many a man has fallen in love with a girl in light so dim he would not have chosen a suit by it.

author: Orison Swett Marden
title: Many a man has finally succeeded only because he has failed after repeated efforts. If he had never met defeat he would never have known any great victory.

author: Stephen B. Leacock
title: Many a man in love with a dimple makes the mistake of marrying the whole girl.

author: J. B. Priestley
title: Many a man is praised for his reserve and so-called shyness when he is simply too proud to risk making a fool of himself.

author: Edgar W. Howe
title: Many a man is saved from being a thief by finding everything locked up.

author: Norman Macewan
title: Many a man never fails because he never tries.

author: Jim Backus
title: Many a man owes his success to his first wife and his second wife to his success.

author: Benjamin Franklin
title: Many a man thinks he is buying pleasure, when he is really selling himself to it.

author: B. C. Forbes
title: Many a man thinks he is patient when, in reality, he is indifferent.

author: Catherine Drinker Bowen
title: Many a man who has known himself at ten forgets himself utterly between ten and thirty.

author: Bruce Barton
title: Many a man who pays rent all his life owns his own home; and many a family has successfully saved for a home only to find itself at last with nothing but a house.

author: Norman Douglas
title: Many a man who thinks to found a home discovers that he has merely opened a tavern for his friends.

author: George Santayana
title: Many possessions, if they do not make a man better, are at least expected to make his children happier; and this pathetic hope is behind many exertions.

author: Sir George Jessel
title: Marriage is a mistake every man should make.

author: Burt Reynolds
title: Marriage is about the most expensive way for the average man to get laundry done.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Marriage is an alliance entered into by a man who can't sleep with the window shut, and a woman who can't sleep with the window open.

author: Ogden Nash
title: Marriage is an alliance entered into by a man who cannot sleep with window shut, and a woman who cannot sleep with the window open.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Marriage is the best state for man in general, and every man is a worst man in proportion to the level he is unfit for marriage.

author: Henry Lewis Stimson
title: Marriage should be a duet - when one sings, the other claps. Joe Murray The only way to make a man trustworthy is to trust him.

author: Jean de la Bruyère
title: Marriage, it seems, confines every man to his proper rank.

author: Jean Kerr
title: Marrying a man is like buying something you've been admiring for a long time in a shop window. You may love it when you get it home, but it doesn't always go with everything else in the house.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Martyrdom is the only way a man can become famous without ability.

author: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh
title: Medicine heals the body, meditation heals the soul. Medicine is outwardly, meditation is inwardly. And man is whole only when medicine and meditation are together in deep harmony.

author: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh
title: Meditation is the only cure for all sicknesses that man is prone to; a single medicine. And I should remind you that the word meditation and medicine come from the same root. Medicine for the body and meditation for the soul. They both bring health.

author: André Maurois
title: Memory is a great artist. For every man and for every woman it makes the recollection of his or her life a work of art and an unfaithful record.

author: André Maurois
title: Memory is a great artist. For every man and for every woman it makes the recollection of his or her life a work of art and an unfaithful record.

author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
title: Men always talk about the most important things to perfect strangers. In the perfect stranger we perceive man himself; the image of a God is not disguised by resemblances to an uncle or doubts of wisdom of a mustache.

author: Barbra Streisand
title: Men are allowed to have passion and commitment for their work... a woman is allowed that feeling for a man, but not her work.

author: Edward Dahlberg
title: Men are mad most of their lives; few live sane, fewer die so. The acts of people are baffling unless we realize that their wits are disordered. Man is driven to justice by his lunacy.

author: Camille Paglia
title: Men are run ragged by female sexuality all their lives. From the beginning of his life to the end, no man ever fully commands any woman. It's an illusion. Men are pussy-whipped. And they know it. That's what the strip clubs are about; not woman as victim, not woman as slave, but woman as goddess.

author: Woody Allen
title: Men learn to love the woman they are attracted to. Women learn to become attracted to the man they fall in love with.

author: Andrea Dworkin
title: Men renounce whatever they have in common with women so as to experience no commonality with women; and what is left, according to men, is one piece of flesh a few inches long, the penis. The penis is sensate; the penis is the man; the man is human; the penis signifies humanity.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Men's actions are too strong for them. Show me a man who has acted, and who has not been the victim and slave of his action.

author: Paul De Man
title: Metaphors are much more tenacious than facts.

author: John Milton
title: Methinks I see in my mind a noble and puissant nation rousing herself like a strong man after sleep, and shaking her invincible locks. Methinks I see her as an eagle mewing her mighty youth, and kindling her undazzled eyes at the full midday beam.

author: Mark Caine
title: Meticulous planning will enable everything a man does to appear spontaneous.

author: Don Marquis
title: Middle age is the time when a man is always thinking that in a week or two he will feel as good as ever.

author: Edith Hamilton
title: Mind and spirit together make up that which separates us from the rest of the animal world, that which enables a man to know the truth and that which enables him to die for the truth.

author: James Allen
title: Mind is the Master - power that molds and makes, and Man is Mind, and ever more he takes the Tool of Thought, and shaping what he wills, brings forth a thousand joys, a thousand ills - He thinks in secret and it comes to pass; Environment is but his looking-glass.

author: William Shakespeare
title: Misery acquaints a man with strange bedfellows.

author: Epicurus
title: Misfortune seldom intrudes upon the wise man; his greatest and highest interests are directed by reason throughout the course of life.

author: Carl Gustav Jung
title: Mistakes are, after all, the foundations of truth, and if a man does not know what a thing is, it is at least an increase in knowledge if he knows what it is not.

author: Adam Clayton Powell
title: Mix a conviction with a man and something happens.

author: Earl Wilson
title: Modern man drives a mortgaged car over a bond-financed highway on credit-card gas.

author: Frank A. Clark
title: Modern man is frantically trying to earn enough to buy things he's too busy to enjoy.

author: Octavio Paz
title: Modern man likes to pretend that his thinking is wide-awake. But this wide-awake thinking has led us into the mazes of a nightmare in which the torture chambers are endlessly repeated in the mirrors of reason.

author: Vaclav Havel
title: Modern man must descend the spiral of his own absurdity to the lowest point; only then can he look beyond it. It is obviously impossible to get around it, jump over it, or simply avoid it.

author: Erich Fromm
title: Modern man thinks he loses something - time - when he does not do things quickly. Yet he does not know what to do with the time he gains - except kill it.

author: Paul De Man
title: Modernity exists in the form of a desire to wipe out whatever came earlier, in the hope of reaching at least a point that could be called a true present, a point of origin that marks a new departure.

author: Benjamin Franklin
title: Money has never made man happy, nor will it, there is nothing in its nature to produce happiness. The more of it one has the more one wants.

author: Kahlil Gibran
title: Money is like love; it kills slowly and painfully the one who withholds it, and enlivens the other who turns it on his fellow man.

author: Benjamin Franklin
title: Money never made a man happy yet, nor will it. The more a man has, the more he wants. Instead of filling a vacuum, it makes one.

author: Albert Camus
title: More and more, when faced with the world of men, the only reaction is one of individualism. Man alone is an end unto himself. Everything one tries to do for the common good ends in failure.

author: Gabriel Heatter
title: More power than all the success slogans ever penned by human hand is the realization for every man that he has but one boss. That boss is the man - he - himself.

author: Andrew Cohen
title: Most men are very attached to the idea of being male, and usually experience a lot of fear and insecurity around the idea of being a man. Most women are very identified with their gender, and also experience a tremendous amount of fear and insecurity.

author: Ben Nicholas
title: Most of life is routine - dull and grubby, but routine is the momentum that keeps a man going. If you wait for inspiration you'll be standing on the corner after the parade is a mile down the street.

author: John Ruskin
title: Mountains are to the rest of the body of the earth, what violent muscular action is to the body of man. The muscles and tendons of its anatomy are, in the mountain, brought out with force and convulsive energy, full of expression, passion, and strength.

author: G. C. Lichtenberg
title: Much can be inferred about a man from his mistress: in her one beholds his weaknesses and his dreams.

author: Charles Caleb Colton
title: Much may be done in those little shreds and patches of time, which every day produces, and which most men throw away, but which nevertheless will make at the end of it no small deduction for the life of man.

author: Walter Savage Landor
title: Music is God's gift to man, the only art of Heaven given to earth, the only art of earth we take to Heaven.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: Music is well said to be the speech of angels; in fact, nothing among the utterances allowed to man is felt to be so divine. It brings us near to the infinite.

author: Queen Elizabeth I
title: Must! Is must a word to be addressed to princes? Little man, little man! thy father, if he had been alive, durst not have used that word.

author: Barry Hannah
title: My dad read history, about a book a day, but only after he retired as a successful bank and insurance man.

author: Bill Goldberg
title: My experience with video games is a far cry from 'WWE 2K17.' Did I ever aspire to be that character? Man, I just wanted to be a hero to kids. Whether it's a character in a video game, a movie or a TV series, it's an accolade that I'm greatly appreciative of.

author: Antonio Villaraigosa
title: My father was predisposed to drunken rages. I would hide under the bed. My sister and I were talking just the other day about the terror a drunken man in a rage can create in a child.

author: Aaron Klug
title: My father was trained as a saddler, but in fact as a young man worked in his father's business of rearing and selling cattle, so he grew up in the countryside.

author: Adelbert von Chamisso
title: My first care the following morning was, to devise some means of discovering the man in the grey cloak.

author: Alex Haley
title: My fondest hope is that 'Roots' may start black, white, brown, red, yellow people digging back for their own roots. Man, that would make me feel 90 feet tall.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: My friend, when a man has anything to tell in this world, the difficulty is not to make him tell it, but to prevent him from telling it too often.

author: Aeschylus
title: My friends, whoever has had experience of evils knows how whenever a flood of ills comes upon mortals, a man fears everything; but whenever a divine force cheers on our voyage, then we believe that the same fate will always blow fair.

author: Beau Willimon
title: My jobs on campaigns were pretty low on the totem pole - I was an advance man.

author: Bertrand Piccard
title: My life and the life of my family has to do with exploration, with adventure. My grandfather was the first man in the stratosphere, and my father was the first to touch the deepest point in the ocean... For me, adventure and exploration is something in the blood.

author: Glenda Jackson
title: My money goes to my agent, then to my accountant and from him to the tax man.

author: Alfred Jodl
title: My most profound confidence is however based upon the fact that at the head of Germany there stands a man by his entire development, his desires, and striving can only have been destined by fate to lead our people into a brighter future.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: My mother married a very good man ... and she is not at all keen on my doing the same.

author: Barbara Park
title: My own pregnancies were all about me, me, me. My aches, my pains, my swollen feet, and my body that looked like the Michelin Man.

author: Blair Underwood
title: My Soul to Keep is the ultimate love story with a black man and a black woman. I call it the ultimate love story. It's about an immortal. We're shooting for this Fall and that's been a six year development right there.

author: Sidonie Gabrielle Colette
title: My true friends have always given me that supreme proof of devotion, a spontaneous aversion for the man I loved.

author: David Herbert Lawrence
title: My whole working philosophy is that the only stable happiness for mankind is that it shall live married in blessed union to woman-kind - intimacy, physical and psychical between a man and his wife. I wish to add that my state of bliss is by no means perfect.

author: Henry David Thoreau
title: Nations! What are nations? Tartars! and Huns! and Chinamen! Like insects they swarm. The historian strives in vain to make them memorable. It is for want of a man that there are so many men. It is individuals that populate the world.

author: Marcus Tullius Cicero
title: Natural ability without education has more often raised a man to glory and virtue than education without natural ability.

author: Karl Marx
title: Natural science will in time incorporate into itself the science of man, just as the science of man will incorporate into itself natural science: there will be one science.

author: Carl Jung
title: Naturally, every age thinks that all ages before it were prejudiced, and today we think this more than ever and are just as wrong as all previous ages that thought so. How often have we not seen the truth condemned! It is sad but unfortunately true that man learns nothing from history.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Nature arms each man with some faculty which enables him to do easily some feat impossible to any other.

author: Jonathan Swift
title: Nature has left every man a capacity of being agreeable, though not of shining in company; and there are a hundred men sufficiently qualified for both who, by a very few faults, that they might correct in half an hour, are not so much as tolerable.

author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow
title: Nature is a revelation of God; Art a revelation of man.

author: Eric Hoffer
title: Nature is a self-made machine, more perfectly automated than any automated machine. To create something in the image of nature is to create a machine, and it was by learning the inner working of nature that man became a builder of machines.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: Nature magically suits a man to his fortunes, by making them the fruit of his character.

author: Paul Boese
title: Nature thrives on patience; man on impatience.

author: Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe
title: Nature understands no jesting. She is always true, always serious, always severe. She is always right, and the errors are always those of man.

author: Benjamin Disraeli
title: Nature, like man, sometimes weeps from gladness.

author: Henry David Thoreau
title: Nay, be a Columbus to whole new continents and worlds within you, opening new channels, not of trade, but of thought. Every man is the lord of a realm beside which the earthly empire of the Czar is but a petty state, a hummock left by the ice.

author: Thomas Alva Edison
title: Nearly every man who develops an idea works at it up to the point where it looks impossible, and then gets discouraged. that's not the place to become discouraged.

author: Daniel Defoe
title: Necessity makes a honest man a knave.

author: Bertrand Russell
title: Neither a man nor a crowd nor a nation can be trusted to act humanely or to think sanely under the influence of a great fear.

author: Dwight D. Eisenhower
title: Neither a wise nor a brave man lies down on the tracks of history to wait for the train of the future to run over him.

author: Fjodor M. Dostojewski
title: Neither man or nation can exist without a sublime idea.

author: Woodrow Wilson
title: Never attempt to murder a man who is committing suicide.

author: Baltasar Gracián
title: Never contend with a man who has nothing to lose.

author: Henry Ward Beecher
title: Never forget what a man says to you when he is angry.

author: Lewis E. Lawes
title: Never give a man up until he has failed at something he likes.

author: Robert Southey
title: Never let any man imagine that he can pursue a good end by evil means, without sinning against his own soul! Any other issue is doubtful; the evil effect on himself is certain.

author: Nelson Algren
title: Never play cards with a man called Doc. Never eat at a place called Mom s. Never sleep with a woman whose troubles are worse than your own.

author: Julius Charles Hare
title: Never put much confidence in such as put no confidence in others. A man prone to suspect evil is mostly looking in his neighbour for what he sees in himself. As to the pure all things are pure, even so to the impure all things are impure.

author: J. C. Hare
title: Never put much confidence in such, as put no confidence in others. A man prone to suspect evil is mostly looking in his neighbor for what he sees in himself. As to the pure all things are pure, even so to the impure all things are impure.

author: Sir Herbert Beerbohm Tree
title: Never say a humorous thing to a man who does not possess humor. He will always use it in evidence against you.

author: Johann Kaspar Lavater
title: Never say you know a man until you have divided an inheritance with him.

author: Anthony Trollope
title: Never think that you're not good enough. A man should never think that. People will take you very much at your own reckoning.

author: Theodore Roosevelt
title: Never throughout history has a man who lived a life of ease left a name worth remembering.

author: John Churton Collins
title: Never trust a man who speaks well of everybody.

author: Billy Connolly
title: Never trust a man who, when left alone in a room with a tea cozy, doesn't try it on.

author: Billy Connolly
title: Never trust a man, who when left alone with a tea cosey... Doesn't try it on.

author: Aesop
title: Never trust the advice of a man in difficulties.

author: Sydney Smith
title: Never try to reason the prejudice out of a man. It was not reasoned into him, and cannot be reasoned out.

author: Franklin D. Roosevelt
title: Never underestimate a man who overestimates himself.

author: Alexander Pope
title: Never was it given to mortal man - To lie so boldly as we women can.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Never, my dear Sir, do you take it into your head that I do not love you; you may settle yourself in full confidence both of my love and my esteem; I love you as a kind man, I value you as a worthy man, and hope in time to reverence you as a man of exemplary piety.

author: Ben Folds
title: Next door, there's an old man who lived to his nineties and one day passed away in his sleep. And his wife, she stayed for a couple of days and passed away. I'm sorry, I know that's a strange way to tell you that I know we belong.

author: Antoine de Saint-Exupéry
title: Night, the beloved. Night, when words fade and things come alive. When the destructive analysis of day is done, and all that is truly important becomes whole and sound again. When man reassembles his fragmentary self and grows with the calm of a tree.

author: Archibald Wavell
title: No amount of study or learning will make a man a leader unless he has the natural qualities of one.

author: Max Muller
title: No burden is so heavy for a man to bear as a succession of happy days.

author: C. S. Lewis
title: No Christian and, indeed, no historian could accept the epigram which defines religion as 'what a man does with his solitude.

author: Cyril Connolly
title: No city should be too large for a man to walk out of in a morning.

author: Albert Claude
title: No doubt, man will continue to weigh and to measure, watch himself grow, and his Universe around him and with him, according to the ever growing powers of his tools.

author: Helen Rowland
title: No girl who is going to marry need bother to win a college degree; she just naturally becomes a ''Master of Arts'' and a ''Doctor of Philosophy'' after catering to an ordinary man for a few years.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: No great man ever complains of want of opportunity.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: No great man lives in vain. The history of the world is but the biography of great men.

author: Marcus Tullius Cicero
title: No liberal man would impute a charge of unsteadiness to another for having changed his opinion.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: No man acquires property without acquiring with it a little arithmetic also.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: No man but a blockhead ever wrote, except for money.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: No man can be a pure specialist without being in the strict sense an idiot.

author: Gloria Steinem
title: No man can call himself liberal, or radical, or even a conservative advocate of fair play, if his work depends in any way on the unpaid or underpaid labor of women at home, or in the office.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: No man can do anything well, who does not esteem his work to be of importance.

author: Sydney Smith
title: No man can ever end with being superior who will not begin with being inferior.

author: B. C. Forbes
title: No man can fight his way to the top and stay at the top without exercising the fullest measure of grit, courage, determination, resolution. Every man who gets anywhere does so because he has first firmly resolved to progress in the world and then has enough stick-to-it-tiveness to transform his resolution into reality. Without resolution, no man can win any worthwhile place among his fellow men.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: No man can help another without helping himself.

author: Thomas Browne
title: No man can justly censure or condemn another, because indeed no man truly knows another.

author: John Milton
title: No man can love freedom heartily, but good men; tbc rest lovc not freedom, but licence.

author: Buckminster Fuller
title: No man can prove upon awakening that he is the man who he thinks went to bed the night before, or that anything that he recollects is anything other than a convincing dream.

author: Dwight L. Moody
title: No man can resolve himself into Heaven.

author: Kahlil Gibran
title: No man can reveal to you nothing but that which already lies half-asleep in the dawning of your knowledge.

author: Napoleon Hill
title: No man can succeed in a line of endeavor which he does not like.

author: George Jean Nathan
title: No man can think clearly when his fists are clenched.

author: Helen Rowland
title: No man can understand why a woman shouldn't prefer a good reputation to a good time.

author: Woodrow Wilson
title: No man can worship God or love his neighbor on an empty stomach.

author: Mary Wollstonecraft
title: No man chooses evil because it is evil; he only mistakes it for happiness.

author: Oscar Wilde
title: No man dies for what he knows to be true. Men die for what they want to be true, for what some terror in their hearts tells them is not true.

author: Jane Austen
title: No man dies of love but on the stage

author: Napoleon Hill
title: No man ever achieved worth-while success who did not, at one time or other, find himself with at least one foot hanging well over the brink of failure.

author: William E. Gladstone
title: No man ever became great or good except through many and great mistakes.

author: Alfred Lord Tennyson
title: No man ever got very high by pulling other people down. The intelligent merchant does not knock his competitors. The sensible worker does not work those who work with him. Don't knock your friends. Don't knock your enemies. Don't knock yourself.

author: Calvin Coolidge
title: No man ever listened himself out of a job.

author: Ruth Benedict
title: No man ever looks at the world with pristine eyes. He sees it edited by a definite set of customs and institutions and ways of thinking.

author: Billy Graham
title: No man ever loved like Jesus. He taught the blind to see and the dumb to speak. He died on the cross to save us. He bore our sins. And now God says, ''Because He did, I can forgive you.''

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: No man ever prayed heartily without learning something.

author: Tuckerman
title: No man flatters the woman he truly loves.

author: Groucho Marx
title: No man goes before his time - unless the boss leaves early.

author: Abraham Lincoln
title: No man has a good enough memory to be a successful liar.

author: Charles Simmons
title: No man has a right to do what he pleases, except when he pleases to do right.

author: Phillips Brooks
title: No man has come to true greatness who has not felt that his life belongs to his race, and that which God gives to him, He gives him for mankind.

author: Woodrow Wilson
title: No man has ever risen to the real stature of spiritual manhood until he has found that it is finer to serve somebody else than it is to serve himself.

author: Denis Diderot
title: No man has received from nature the right to give orders to others. Freedom is a gift from heaven, and every individual of the same species has the right to enjoy it as soon as he is in enjoyment of his reason.

author: Ansel Adams
title: No man has the right to dictate what other men should perceive, create or produce, but all should be encouraged to reveal themselves, their perceptions and emotions, and to build confidence in the creative spirit.

author: Channing Pollock
title: No man in the world has more courage than the man who can stop after eating one peanut.

author: James Baldwin
title: No man is a devil in his own mind.

author: William Feather
title: No man is a failure who is enjoying life.

author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel
title: No man is a hero to his valet. This is not because the hero is no hero, but because the valet is a valet.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: No man is a hypocrite in his pleasures.

author: Louis Bernieres
title: No man is a man until he has been a soldier.

author: Florence Scovel Shinn
title: No man is a success in business unless he loves his work.

author: Theodore Roosevelt
title: No man is above the law, and no man is below it.

author: John Donne
title: No man is an island entire of itself; every man is a piece of the continent, a part of the main.

author: John Donne
title: No man is an Island, entire of itself.

author: Francis Quarles
title: No man is born unto himself alone; who lives unto himself, he lives to none.

author: Douglas Macarthur
title: No man is entitled to the blessings of freedom unless he be vigilant in its preservation.

author: Sir Walter Raleigh
title: No man is esteemed for colorful garments except by fools and women.

author: Napoleon Hill
title: No man is ever whipped until he quits in his own mind.

author: Epictetus
title: No man is free who is not a master of himself.

author: Abraham Lincoln
title: No man is good enough to govern another man without his consent.

author: Henry Miller
title: No man is great enough or wise enough for any of us to surrender our destiny to. The only way in which anyone can lead us is to restore to us the belief in our own guidance.

author: Solon
title: No man is happy; he is at best fortunate.

author: Diogenes of Sinope
title: No man is hurt but by himself

author: Theodore Roosevelt
title: No man is justified in doing evil on the ground of expediency.

author: Christopher Morley
title: No man is lonely while eating spaghetti; it requires so much attention.

author: Miguel de Cervantes
title: No man is more than another unless he does more than another.

author: W. Osier
title: No man is really happy or safe without a hobby, and it makes precious little difference what the outside interest may be.

author: Benjamin Disraeli
title: No man is regular in his attendance at the House of Commons until he is married.

author: Oscar Wilde
title: No man is rich enough to buy back his own past.

author: Henry Ward Beecher
title: No man is sane who does not know how to be insane on proper occasions.

author: Michel Eyquem De Montaigne
title: No man is so exquisitely honest or upright in living, but that ten times in his life he might not lawfully be hanged.

author: Ben Johnson
title: No man is so foolish but he may sometimes give another good counsel, and no man so wise that he may not easily err if he takes no other counsel than his own. He that is taught only by himself has a fool for a master.

author: Jean de la Bruyère
title: No man is so perfect, so necessary to his friends, as to give them no cause to miss him less.

author: Henry Ward Beecher
title: No man is such a conqueror, as the one that has defeated himself.

author: William Hazlitt
title: No man is truly great who is great only in his lifetime. The test of greatness is the page of history.

author: Robert Louis Stevenson
title: No man is useless while he has a friend.

author: Plautus
title: No man is wise enough by himself.

author: Charles Caleb Colton
title: No man is wise enough, or good enough to be trusted with unlimited power.

author: Theodore Roosevelt
title: No man is worth his salt who is not ready at all times to risk his well-being, to risk his body, to risk his life, in a great cause.

author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
title: No man knows he is young while he is young.

author: Bram Stoker
title: No man knows till he has suffered from the night how sweet and dear to his heart and eye the morning can be.

author: Friedrich Nietzsche
title: No man lies so boldly as the man who is indignant.

author: Henry Brooks Adams
title: No man likes to have his intelligence or good faith questioned, especially if he has doubts about it himself.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: No man likes to live under the eye of perpetual disapprobation.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: No man lives without jostling and being jostled; in all ways he has to elbow himself through the world, giving and receiving offence.

author: Henry Brooks Adams
title: No man means all he says, and yet very few say all they mean, for words are slippery and thought is viscous.

author: Elbert Hubbard
title: No man needs a vacation so much as the man who has just had one.

author: Theodore Roosevelt
title: No man needs sympathy because he has to work. Far and away the best prize that life offers is the chance to work hard at work worth doing.

author: Phillips Brooks
title: No man or woman can be strong, gentle, pure, and good, without the world being better for it and without someone being helped and comforted by the very existence of that goodness.

author: John S. Bonnell
title: No man or woman has achieved an effective personality who is not self-disciplined. Such discipline must not be an end in itself, but must be directed to the development of resolute Christian character.

author: Denis Waitley
title: No man or woman is an island. To exist just for yourself is meaningless. You can achieve the most satisfaction when you feel related to some greater purpose in life, something greater than yourself.

author: Alan Alda
title: No man or woman of the humblest sort can really be strong, gentle and good, without the world being better for it, without somebody being helped and comforted by the very existence of that goodness.

author: John Steinbeck
title: No man really knows about other human beings. The best he can do is to suppose that they are like himself.,

author: Oliver Cromwell
title: No man rises so high as he knows not whither he goes.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: No man sees far, most see no farther than their noses.

author: George Mcgovern
title: No man should advocate a course in private that he's ashamed to admit in public.

author: A. W. Tozer
title: No man should desire to be happy who is not at the same time holy. He should spend his efforts in seeking to know and do the will of God, leaving to Christ the matter of how happy he should be.

author: J. Robert Oppenheimer
title: No man should escape our universities without knowing how little he knows.,

author: Hitopadesa
title: No man should ever display his bravery unless he is prepared for battle, nor bear the marks of defiance, until he has experienced the abilities of his enemy.

author: Honoré de Balzac
title: No man should marry until he has studied anatomy and dissected at least one woman.

author: Bernard M. Baruch
title: No man should think himself a zero, and think he can do nothing about the state of the world.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: No man should travel until he has learned the language of the country he visits. Otherwise he voluntarily makes himself a great baby-so helpless and so ridiculous.

author: Lord Chesterfield
title: No man tastes pleasures truly, who does not earn them by previous business; and few people do business well, who do nothing else.

author: Woodrow Wilson
title: No man that does not see visions will ever realize any high hope or undertake any high enterprise.

author: Anthony Trollope
title: No man thinks there is much ado about nothing when the ado is about himself.

author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
title: No man thoroughly understands a truth until he has contended against it.

author: Ezra Pound
title: No man understands a deep book until he has seen and lived at least part of its contents.

author: Socrates
title: No man undertakes a trade he has not learned, even the meanest; yet everyone thinks himself sufficiently qualified for the hardest of all trades, that of government.

author: Gerald W. Johnson
title: No man was ever endowed with a right without being at the same time saddled with a responsibility.

author: Samuel Johnson
title:
No man was ever great by imitation.,
,
,

author: Terence
title: No man was ever so completely skilled in the conduct of life, as not to receive new information from age and experience.

author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge
title: No man was ever yet a great poet, without begin at the same time a profound philosopher.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: No man who has once heartily and wholly laughed can be altogether irreclaimably bad.

author: William J. Durant
title: No man who is in a hurry is quite civilized.

author: Demosthenes
title: No man who is not willing to help himself has any right to apply to his friends, or to the gods.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: No man who is occupied in doing a very difficult thing, and doing it very well, ever loses his self-respect.

author: John Milton
title: No man who knows aught, can be so stupid to deny that all men naturally were born free.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: No man will be a sailor who has contrivance enough to get himself into a jail; for being in a ship is being in a jail, with the chance of being drowned. A man in a jail has more room, better food and commonly better company.

author: Thomas Jefferson
title: No man will ever bring out of the Presidency the reputation which carries him into it.

author: David Seabury
title: No man will work for your interests unless they are his.

author: Tallulah Bankhead
title: No man worth his salt, no man of spirit and spine, no man for whom I could have any respect, could rejoice in the identification of Tallulah's husband. It's tough enough to be bogged down in a legend. It would be even tougher to marry one.

author: Nathaniel Hawthorne
title: No man, for any considerable period, can wear one face to himself, and another to the multitude, without finally getting bewildered as to which may be true.

author: Benjamin Haydon
title: No man, perhaps, is so wicked as to commit evil for its own sake. Evil is generally committed under the hope of some advantage the pursuit of virtue seldom obtains. Yet the most successful result of the most virtuous heroism is never without its alloy.

author: Booker T. Washington
title: No man, who continues to add something to the material, intellectual and moral well-being of the place in which he lives, is left long without proper reward.

author: Henry Louis Mencken
title: No matter how happily a woman may be married, it always pleases her to discover that there is a nice man who wishes that she were not.

author: Henry Miller
title: No matter how vast, how total, the failure of man here on earth, the work of man will be resumed elsewhere. War leaders talk of resuming operations on this front and that, but man's front embraces the whole universe.

author: Charles Horton Cooley
title: No matter what a man does, he is not fully sane or human unless there is a spirit of freedom in him, a soul unconfined by purpose and larger than the practicable world.

author: Mary Wortley Montagu
title: No modest man ever did or ever will make a fortune.

author: John Knox
title: No one else holds or has held the place in the heart of the world which Jesus holds. Other gods have been as devoutly worshipped; no other man has been so devoutly loved.

author: Blaise Pascal
title: No one is offended at not seeing everything; but one does not like to be mistaken, and that perhaps arises from the fact that man naturally cannot see everything, and that naturally he cannot err in the side he looks at, since the perceptions of our senses are always true.

author: A. Alvarez
title: No one is promiscuous in his way of dying. A man who has decided to hang himself will never jump in front of a train.

author: Harriet Beecher Stowe
title: No one is so thoroughly superstitious as the godless man.

author: Aristotle
title: No one loves the man whom he fears.

author: A. Bartlett Giamatti
title: No one man is superior to the game.

author: Marguerite Duras
title: No other human being, no woman, no poem or music, book or painting can replace alcohol in its power to give man the illusion of real creation.

author: Bruce Barton
title: No sex, age, or condition is above or below the absolute necessity of modesty; but without it one vastly beneath the rank of man.

author: Albrecht Durer
title: No single man can be taken as a model for a perfect figure, for no man lives on earth who is endowed with the whole of beauty.

author: Frank Lloyd Wright
title: No stream rises higher than its source. What ever man might build could never express or reflect more than he was. He could record neither more nor less than he had learned of life when the buildings were built.

author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
title: No such thing as a man willing to be honest - that would be like a blind man willing to see.,

author: B. F. Skinner
title: No theory changes what it is a theory about; man remains what he has always been.

author: Letitia Elizabeth Landon
title: No thoroughly occupied man was ever yet very miserable.

author: Plato
title: No trace of slavery ought to mix with the studies of the freeborn man. No study, pursued under compulsion, remains rooted in the memory.

author: William Hazlitt
title: No wise man can have a contempt for the prejudices of others; and he should even stand in a certain awe of his own, as if they were aged parents and monitors. They may in the end prove wiser than he.

author: Jonathan Swift
title: No wise man ever wished to be younger.

author: Alexander Pope
title: No woman ever hates a man for being in love with her, but many a woman hate a man for being a friend to her.

author: William Hazlitt
title: No young man believes he shall ever die.

author: Gabriel Garcia Marquez
title: No, not rich. I am a poor man with money, which is not the same thing.

author: Sydney Harris
title: Nobody can be so amusingly arrogant as a young man who has just discovered an old idea and thinks it is his own.

author: Malcolm X
title: Nobody can give you freedom. Nobody can give you equality or justice or anything. If you're a man, you take it.,

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Nobody can write the life of a man but those who have eat and drunk and lived in social intercourse with him.

author: Buzz Aldrin
title: Nobody ever asks who was the seventh person on the Moon. The only thing they know is who's number one and who's number two. Does anybody know who the last man was?

author: Bryan Robson
title: Nobody is that thick-skinned that it doesn't hurt you. Still, you always know what happens in football. I have got used to criticism, I suppose, having been high profile with England and Man U.

author: C. Wright Mills
title: Nobody talks more of free enterprise and competition and of the best man winning than the man who inherited his father's store or farm.

author: R. Davies
title: Nobody who looks as though he enjoyed life is ever called distinguished, though he is a man in a million.

author: Mahatma Gandhi
title: Non-violence is the greatest force at the disposal of mankind. It is mightier than the mightiest weapon of destruction devised by the ingenuity of man.,

author: Mahatma Gandhi
title: Non-violence requires a double faith, faith in God and also faith in man.,

author: R. D. Laing
title: Normality highly values its normal man. It educates children to lose themselves and to become absurd, and thus to be normal. Normal men have killed perhaps 100, 000 of their fellow normal men in the last fifty years.

author: Alexander Pope
title: Not always actions show the man; we find who does a kindness is not therefore kind.

author: Plutarch
title: Not by lamentations and mournful chants ought we to celebrate the funeral of a good man, but by hymns, for in ceasing to be numbered with mortals he enters upon the heritage of a diviner life.

author: William Wordsworth
title: Not Chaos, not the darkest pit of lowest Erebus, nor aught of blinder vacancy, scooped out by help of dreams - can breed such fear and awe as fall upon us often when we look into our Minds, into the Mind of Man.

author: Pindar
title: Not every truth is the better for showing its face undisguised; and often silence is the wisest thing for a man to heed.

author: Carl Sandburg
title: Not often in the story of mankind does a man arrive on earth who is both steel and velvet, who is as hard as rock and soft as drifting fog, who holds in his heart and mind the paradox of terrible storm and peace unspeakable and perfect.

author: Alexis de Tocqueville
title: Not only does democracy make every man forget his ancestors, but also clouds their view of their descendants and isolates them from their contemporaries. Each man is for ever thrown back on himself alone, and there is danger that he may be shut up in the solitude of his own heart.

author: Arianna Huffington
title: Not only is it harder to be a man, it is also harder to become one.

author: Saskya Pandita
title: Not to be cheered by praise, not to be grieved by blame, but to know thoroughly ones own virtues or powers are the characteristics of an excellent man.

author: Friedrich Nietzsche
title: Not when truth is dirty, but when it is shallow, does the enlightened man dislike to wade into its waters.

author: Brooks Atkinson
title: Nothing a man writes can please him as profoundly as something he does with his back, shoulders and hands. For writing is an artificial activity. It is a lonely and private substitute for conversation.

author: Norman Douglas
title: Nothing ages a man like living always with the same woman.

author: Thomas Love Peacock
title: Nothing can be more obvious than all animals were created solely and exclusively for the use of man.

author: Henry Louis Mencken
title: Nothing can come out of the artist that is not in the man.

author: Lord George Byron
title: Nothing can confound a wise man more than laughter from a dunce.

author: Thomas Jefferson
title: Nothing can stop the man with the right mental attitude from achieving his goal; nothing on earth can help the man with the wrong mental attitude.

author: Samuel Johnson
title: Nothing flatters a man as much as the happiness of his wife; he is always proud of himself as the source of it.

author: Umberto Eco
title: Nothing gives a fearful man more courage than another's fear.

author: Pearl S. Buck
title: Nothing in life is as good as the marriage of true minds between man and woman. As good? It is life itself. ''

author: Friedrich Nietzsche
title: Nothing is beautiful, only man: on this piece of naivete rests all aesthetics, it is the first truth of aesthetics. Let us immediately add its second: nothing is ugly but degenerate man - the domain of aesthetic judgment is therewith defined.

author: Demosthenes
title: Nothing is easier than self-deceit. For what each man wishes, that he also believes to be true.

author: Epicurus
title: Nothing is enough for the man to whom enough is to little.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Nothing is ever accomplished by a reasonable man.

author: Andrew Bernstein
title: Nothing is given to man on earth - struggle is built into the nature of life, and conflict is possible - the hero is the man who lets no obstacle prevent him from pursuing the values he has chosen.

author: Plutarch
title: Nothing is harder to direct than a man in prosperity; nothing more easily managed that one is adversity.

author: A. H. Weiler
title: Nothing is impossible for the man who doesn't have to do it himself.

author: Honoré Gabriel Riqueti Count of Mirabeau
title: Nothing is impossible to the man who will.

author: Gilbert K. Chesterton
title: Nothing is poetical if plain daylight is not poetical; and no monster should amaze us if the normal man does not amaze.

author: Blaise Pascal
title: Nothing is so intolerable to man as being fully at rest, without a passion, without business, without entertainment, without care.

author: André Gide
title: Nothing is so silly as the expression of a man who is being complimented.

author: Alice S. Rossi
title: Nothing is so threatening to conventional values as a man who does not want to work or does not want to work at a challenging job, and most people are disturbed if a man in a well-paying job indicates ambivalence or dislike toward it.

author: Plautus
title: Nothing is there more friendly to a man than a friend in need.

author: George Bernard Shaw
title: Nothing makes a man so selfish as work.

author: Decimus Magnus Ausonius
title: Nothing more detestable does the earth produce than an ungrateful man.

author: C. Patmore
title: Nothing remains with man unless it is insinuated with some delight.

author: Adlai E. Stevenson II
title: Nothing so dates a man as to decry the younger generation.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: Nothing so lifts a man from all his mean imprisonments, were it but for moments, as true admiration.

author: Eric Butterworth
title: Nothing stops the man who desires to achieve. Every obstacle is simply a course to develop his achievement muscle. It's a strengthening of his powers of accomplishment.

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: Nothing that was worthy in the past departs; no truth or goodness realized by man ever dies, or can die.

author: S. I. Hayakawa
title: Notice the difference between what happens when a man says to himself, I have failed three times,  and what happens when he says, I am a failure.

author: Kin Hubbard
title: Now and then an innocent man is sent to the legislature.

author: A. E. Housman
title:
Now hollow fires burn out to black, ,
 And lights are guttering low: ,
 Square your shoulders, lift your pack, ,
 And leave your friends and go. ,
  ,
 Oh never fear, man, nought's to dread, ,
 Look not to left nor right: ,
 In all the endless road you tread ,
 There's nothing but the night.

author: David Herbert Lawrence
title: Now man cannot live without some vision of himself.

author: William S. Burroughs
title: Now what sort of man or woman or monster would stroke a centipede I have ever seen? ''And here is my good big centipede!'' If such a man exists, I say kill him without more ado. He is a traitor to the human race.

author: Agnes Smedley
title: Now, being a girl, I was ashamed of my body and my lack of strength. So I tried to be a man. I shot, rode, jumped, and took part in all the fights of the boys.

author: Billy Wilder
title: Now, what is it which makes a scene interesting? If you see a man coming through a doorway, it means nothing. If you see him coming through a window - that is at once interesting.

author: Ovid
title: Nowadays nothing but money counts: a fortune brings honors, friendships, the poor man everywhere lies low.

author: Geoffrey Chaucer
title: Nowhere so busy a man as he than he, and yet he seemed busier than he was.

author: William Shakespeare
title: O how wretched is that poor man that hangs on princes favors! There is betwixt that smile we would aspire to, that sweet aspect of princes, and their ruin, more pangs and fears than wars or women have, and when he falls, he falls like Lucifer, never to hope again.

author: William Cowper
title: O, popular applause! what heart of man is proof against thy sweet, seducing charms?

author: Thomas Carlyle
title: Of all acts of man repentance is the most divine. The greatest of all faults is to be conscious of none.

author: Charles Dickens
title: Of all bad listeners, the worst and most terrible to encounter is the man who is so fond of listening that he wishes to hear, not only your conversation, but that of every other person in the room.

author: Booker T. Washington
title: Of all forms of slavery there is none that is so harmful and degrading as that form of slavery which tempts one human being to hate another by reason of his race or color. One man cannot hold another man down in the ditch without remaining down in the ditch with him.

author: Mark Twain
title: Of all God's creatures there is only one that cannot be made the slave of the lash. That one is the cat. If man could be crossed with a cat it would improve man, but it would deteriorate the cat.

author: John Ruskin
title: Of all God's gifts to the sighted man, color is holiest, the most divine, the most solemn.

author: Marcus Tullius Cicero
title: Of all nature's gifts to the human race, what is sweeter to a man than his children?

author: G. C. Lichtenberg
title: Of all the inventions of man I doubt whether any was more easily accomplished than that of a Heaven.

author: Charles Caleb Colton

author: Anatole France
title: Of all the ways of defining man, the worst is the one which makes him out to be a rational animal.

author: Chimamanda Adichie
title: Of course I am not worried about intimidating men. The type of man who will be intimidated by me is exactly the type of man I have no interest in.

author: Phyllis Mcginley
title: Of course we women gossip on occasion. But our appetite for it is not as avid as a man s. It is in the boys gyms, the college fraternity houses, the club locker rooms, the paneled offices of business that gossip reaches its luxuriant flower.

author: Alexander Pope
title: Of Manners gentle, of Affections mild; In Wit a man; Simplicity, a child.

author: Confucius
title: Of neighborhoods, benevolence is the most beautiful. How can the man be considered wise who when he had the choice does not settle in benevolence.

author: Adelbert von Chamisso
title: Of what use were wings to a man fast bound in chains of iron?
